{"uri": "8163423012", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "18:42:09", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T18:42:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T18:40:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13498933/What-know-Boeings-spaceflight-carrying-NASA-astronauts.html", "title": "What to know about Boeing's first spaceflight carrying NASA astronauts", "body": "CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. (AP) - After years of stumbles and delays, Boeing has finally launched astronauts to the International Space Station for NASA.\n\nIt\u00b4s the first flight of Boeing\u00b4s Starliner capsule with a crew on board, a pair of NASA pilots who will check out the spacecraft during the test drive and a weeklong stay at the space station.\n\nNASA turned to U.S. companies for astronaut rides after the space shuttles were retired. Elon Musk's SpaceX has made nine taxi trips for NASA since 2020, while Boeing has managed only a pair of empty test flights.\n\nProvided this tryout goes well, NASA will alternate between Boeing and SpaceX to get astronauts to and from the space station.\n\nA look at the newest ride and its shakedown cruise:\n\nWhite with black and blue trim, Boeing's Starliner capsule is about 10 feet (3 meters) tall and 15 feet (4.5 meters) in diameter. It can fit up to seven people, though NASA crews typically will number four. The company settled on the name Starliner nearly a decade ago, a twist on the name of Boeing\u00b4s early Stratoliner and the current Dreamliner planes.\n\nNASA astronauts Suni Williams, left, and Butch Wilmore pose for a photo after leaving the operations and checkout building for a trip to launch pad at Space Launch Complex 41 Wednesday, June 5, 2024, in Cape Canaveral, Fla. The two astronauts are scheduled to liftoff later today on the Boeing Starliner capsule for a trip to the international space station. (AP Photo/Chris O'Meara)\n\nNo one was aboard Boeing\u00b4s two previous Starliner test flights. The first, in 2019, was hit with software trouble so severe that its empty capsule couldn\u00b4t reach the station until the second try in 2022. Then last summer, weak parachutes and flammable tape cropped up that needed to be fixed or removed. Wednesday's launch was the third try with astronauts; two earlier countdowns were scuttled by rocket-related issues.\n\nVeteran NASA astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams are retired Navy captains who spent months aboard the space station years ago. They joined the test flight after the original crew bowed out as the delays piled up. Wilmore, 61, is a former combat pilot from Mount Juliet, Tennessee, and Williams, 58, is a helicopter pilot from Needham, Massachusetts.\n\nStarliner blasted off on United Launch Alliance\u00b4s Atlas V rocket from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station. It's the first time astronauts have ridden an Atlas since NASA\u00b4s Project Mercury, starting with John Glenn when he became the first American to orbit the Earth in 1962. Now 62 years later, Wednesday's launch was the 100th for the top-of-the-line Atlas V, which is used to hoist satellites as well as spacecraft. ULA is a joint venture of Boeing and Lockheed Martin.\n\nStarliner should reach the space station with its seven residents on Thursday. Starliner will remain docked for just over a week, undergoing checkouts before landing in the American West.\n\nBoth Boeing and SpaceX's capsules are designed to be autonomous and reusable. This Starliner is the same one that made the first test flight in 2019. Unlike the SpaceX Dragons, Starliner has traditional hand controls and switches alongside touchscreens and, according to the astronauts, is more like NASA\u00b4s Orion capsules for moon missions. Plans called for Wilmore and Williams to briefly take manual control to test out the systems on their way to the space station.\n\nNASA gave Boeing, a longtime space contractor, more than $4 billion to develop the capsule, while SpaceX got $2.6 billion. SpaceX already was delivering supplies to the space station, and merely refashioned its cargo capsule for crew. While SpaceX uses the boss' Teslas to get astronauts to the launch pad, Boeing has a more traditional \"astrovan.\"\n\nOne big difference at flight\u00b4s end: Starliner lands on the ground with cushioning airbags, while Dragon splashes into the sea.\n\nBoeing is committed to six Starliner trips for NASA after this one, which will take the company to the station\u00b4s planned end in 2030. Boeing has said a fifth seat will be available to private clients. SpaceX periodically sells seats to tycoons and even countries eager to get their citizens to the station for a couple weeks, but these rides are separate from NASA's dedicated six-month missions.\n\nComing soon: Sierra Space\u00b4s mini shuttle, Dream Chaser, which will attempt to deliver cargo to the station later this year, before accepting passengers. It is due to launch on ULA's new Vulcan rocket, the eventual successor to the Atlas V.\n\nThe Associated Press Health and Science Department receives support from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute\u00b4s Science and Educational Media Group. The AP is solely responsible for all content.\n\nBoeing's Starliner capsule, atop an Atlas V rocket, sits on the launch pad at Space Launch Complex 41 Friday, May 31, 2024, in Cape Canaveral, Fla. NASA astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams will launch aboard the rocket to the International Space Station, scheduled for liftoff on June 1. (AP Photo/Chris O'Meara)\n\nBoeing's Starliner capsule, atop an Atlas V rocket, sits on the launch pad at Space Launch Complex 41 Friday, May 31, 2024, in Cape Canaveral, Fla. NASA astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams will launch aboard the rocket to the International Space Station, scheduled for liftoff on June 1. (AP Photo/Chris O'Meara)\n\nBoeing's Starliner capsule, atop an Atlas V rocket, lifts off from launch pad at Space Launch Complex 41 Wednesday, June 5, 2024, in Cape Canaveral, Fla. NASA astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams are headed to the International Space Station. (AP Photo/Chris O'Meara)\n\nBoeing's Starliner capsule, atop an Atlas V rocket, lifts off from launch pad at Space Launch Complex 41 Wednesday, June 5, 2024, in Cape Canaveral, Fla. NASA astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams are headed to the International Space Station. (AP Photo/Chris O'Meara)", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "https://i.dailymail.co.uk/1s/2024/06/05/19/wire-85760297-1717611705-731_636x382.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9622079", "eventUri": "eng-9622079", "location": null, {"uri": "2024-06-380074135", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "20:00:18", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T20:00:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T19:58:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://wsvn.com/news/us-world/boeing-launches-nasa-astronauts-for-the-first-time-after-years-of-delays-2/", "title": "Boeing launches NASA astronauts for the first time after years of delays", "body": "A United Launch Alliance Atlas V rocket with Boeing's Starliner spacecraft aboard launches from Space Launch Complex 41 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station, Wednesday, June 5, 2024, in Florida. NASA's Boeing Crew Flight Test is the first launch with astronauts of the Boeing spacecraft and United Launch Alliance Atlas V rocket to the International Space Station as part of the agency's Commercial Crew Program. Credits: NASA/Joel Kowsky\n\nCAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. (AP) -- Boeing launched astronauts for the first time Wednesday, belatedly joining SpaceX as a second taxi service for NASA.\n\nA pair of NASA test pilots blasted off aboard Boeing's Starliner capsule for the International Space Station, the first to fly the new spacecraft.\n\nThe trip by Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams was expected to take 25 hours, with an arrival Thursday. They will spend just over a week at the orbiting lab before climbing back into Starliner for a remote desert touchdown in the western U.S. on June 14.\n\n\"Let's get going!\" Wilmore called out a few minutes before liftoff.\n\nHalf an hour later, he and Williams were safely in orbit and giving chase to the space station. Back at Cape Canaveral, the relieved launch controllers stood and applauded. After all the trouble leading up to Wednesday's launch, including two scrapped countdowns, everything went smoothly before and during liftoff, prompting congratulations from SpaceX's Elon Musk and others.\n\n\"Today it all lined up,\" said Boeing program manager Mark Nappi.\n\nYears late because of spacecraft flaws, Starliner's crew debut comes as the company struggles with unrelated safety issues on its airplane side.\n\nWilmore and Williams -- retired Navy captains and former space station residents -- stressed repeatedly before the launch that they had full confidence in Boeing's ability to get it right with this test flight. Crippled by bad software, Starliner's initial test flight in 2019 without a crew had to be repeated before NASA would let its astronauts strap in. The 2022 do-over went much better, but parachute problems later cropped up and flammable tape had to be removed from the capsule.\n\nWednesday's launch was the third attempt with astronauts since early May, coming after a pair of rocket-related problems, most recently last weekend. A small helium leak in the spacecraft's propulsion system also caused delays, but remained extremely low and manageable.\n\n\"It's just a tough endeavor to get to flight and huge kudos to the entire team for getting there,\" said Steve Stich, NASA's commercial crew program manager.\n\nBoeing was hired alongside Elon Musk's SpaceX a decade ago to ferry NASA's astronauts to and from the space station. The space agency wanted two competing U.S. companies for the job in the wake of the space shuttles' retirement, paying $4.2 billion to Boeing and just over half that to SpaceX, which refashioned the capsule it was using to deliver station supplies.\n\nSpaceX launched astronauts into orbit in 2020, becoming the first private business to achieve what only three countries -- Russia, the U.S. and China -- had mastered. It has taken nine crews to the space station for NASA and three private groups for a Houston company that charters flights.\n\nThe liftoff from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station was the 100th of an Atlas V for rocket maker United Launch Alliance. It was the first ride for astronauts on an Atlas rocket since John Glenn's Mercury era more than 60 years ago; the rocket usually launches satellites and other spacecraft.\n\nDespite the Atlas V's perfect record, the human presence cranked up the tension for the scores of NASA and Boeing employees gathered at Cape Canaveral and Mission Control in Houston.\n\nBoeing's Starliner and SpaceX's Dragon are designed to be fully autonomous and reusable. Wilmore and Williams occasionally will take manual control of Starliner on their way to the space station, to check out its systems. The only snag early in the flight involved the capsule's cooling system. More water was used than expected before the radiators took over in orbit. The tank will be refilled before the ride home.\n\nIf the mission goes well, NASA will alternate between SpaceX and Boeing for taxi flights, beginning next year. The backup pilot for this test flight, Mike Fincke, will strap in for Starliner's next trip.\n\n\"This is exciting. We built up to this moment for years and years, and it finally happened,\" Fincke said from neighboring Kennedy Space Center. \"I feel like the whole planet was cheering for them.\"\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8163401490", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "18:22:15", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T18:22:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T18:21:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.staradvertiser.com/2024/06/05/breaking-news/boeings-starliner-spacecraft-sends-first-astronaut-crew-to-orbit/", "title": "Boeing's Starliner spacecraft sends first astronaut crew to orbit | Honolulu Star-Advertiser", "body": "A United Launch Alliance Atlas V rocket carrying two astronauts aboard Boeing's Starliner-1 Crew Flight Test (CFT), is launched on a mission to the International Space Station, in Cape Canaveral, Florida, today.\n\nCAPE CANAVERAL, Florida >> Boeing's new Starliner capsule flew its first crew of astronauts to space today from Florida in a much-delayed test mission to the International Space Station, a milestone in the aerospace giant's ambitions to step up its competition with Elon Musk's SpaceX.\n\nThe CST-100 Starliner, with astronauts Barry \"Butch\" Wilmore and Sunita \"Suni\" Williams aboard, lifted off from the Cape Canaveral Space Force Station, strapped to an Atlas V rocket furnished and flown by the Boeing-Lockheed Martin joint venture United Launch Alliance (ULA).\n\nThe gumdrop-shaped capsule and its crew was headed for a rendezvous with the International Space Station (ISS) following years of technical problems, delays and a successful 2022 test mission to the orbital laboratory without astronauts aboard.\n\nThe Atlas V's engines thundered to life today in flaming clouds of exhaust and coolant-water vapor as the spacecraft roared off its launch pad into sunny skies from Florida's Atlantic Coast.\n\nThe rocket's upper stage separated from its lower section about four minutes into flight, followed by Starliner's separation from the second stage. Now on its own, the spacecraft fired onboard thrusters to start pushing itself into orbit, mission managers said, a process that starts its 24-hour catch-up journey with the ISS, which orbits some 250 miles (400 km) above Earth.\n\nStarliner will need to execute precise maneuvers to dock with the ISS as planned on Thursday, demonstrate it can stay docked for about eight days, then safely return the two astronauts to Earth.\n\nBoeing intends for Starliner to compete with SpaceX's Crew Dragon capsule, which since 2020 has been NASA's only vehicle for sending ISS crew members to orbit from U.S. soil.\n\nMark Nappi, Boeing's Starliner program chief, told a news conference that tens of thousands of things have to go right during Starliner's launch, and that today \"it all lined up.\"\n\n\"We had just a perfect countdown and launch. ... We're on orbit with Butch and Suni, it's been a longtime coming. And we're really, really proud,\" Nappi said.\n\nBoeing shares were up less than 1% in early afternoon trade.\n\n\"Starliner ascends to the heavens,\" NASA chief Bill Nelson wrote on social media, congratulating Boeing, ULA and the U.S. space agency.\n\nNelson called the launch \"a milestone achievement for the future of spaceflight. Butch and Suni - safe travels through the stars. See you back home.\"\n\nLast-minute issues had nixed the Starliner's first two crewed launch attempts. A May 6 countdown was halted two hours before liftoff over three issues that required weeks of extra scrutiny. Another try last Saturday was halted less than four minutes before liftoff because of a launchpad computer glitch.\n\nThe inaugural crew for the seven-seat Starliner includes two veteran NASA astronauts in Wilmore, 61, a retired U.S. Navy captain and fighter pilot, and Williams, 58, a former Navy helicopter test pilot with experience flying more than 30 different aircraft.\n\nThey have spent a combined 500 days in space over the course of two ISS missions each. Wilmore is the designated commander for the flight, with Williams in the pilot seat.\n\nBOEING AMBITIONS\n\nBoeing, with its commercial airplane operations rocked by a series of crises involving its 737 MAX jetliners, needs a win in space for its Starliner venture, already several years behind schedule and more than $1.5 billion over budget.\n\nThe longtime NASA contractor has built modules for the decades-old ISS and rockets designed to loft astronauts toward the moon. But Boeing never before built its own operational spacecraft, a feat complicated by years of software issues, technical glitches and management shakeups on the Starliner program.\n\nMeanwhile, SpaceX's Crew Dragon has become a dependable taxi to orbit for NASA. That capsule and Starliner are among the first in a new generation of privately built spacecraft - seeded with NASA funding - designed to fly astronauts to low-Earth orbit and the moon under the agency's Artemis program.\n\nStarliner would compete head-to-head with SpaceX's Crew Dragon capsule, which since 2020 has been NASA's only vehicle for sending ISS crew members to orbit from U.S. soil.\n\n\"Congratulations on a successful launch,\" Musk wrote on social media.\n\nAlthough Starliner is designed to fly autonomously, the crew can assume control of it if necessary. The test flight calls for Wilmore and Williams to practice maneuvering manually en route to ISS.\n\nWilmore and Williams are due to join ISS's current seven resident crew members before riding the capsule back to Earth for a parachute and airbag-assisted landing in the U.S. Desert Southwest - a first for a crewed NASA mission.\n\nGetting Starliner to this point has been a fraught process for Boeing under its $4.2 billion fixed-priced contract with NASA, which wants the redundancy of two different U.S. rides to the ISS, an outpost expected to retire around 2030.\n\nMeanwhile, SpaceX's fourth test launch of its Starship rocket system, another step in its quest to build a reusable satellite launcher and moon lander, is due for liftoff on Thursday from Texas.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8163080183", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "14:30:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T14:30:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T14:29:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.nbcboston.com/news/business/money-report/boeing-starliner-to-make-another-attempt-at-launching-nasa-astronauts/3390078/", "title": "Boeing Starliner to make another attempt to launch NASA astronauts", "body": "Get Boston local news, weather forecasts, lifestyle and entertainment stories to your inbox. Sign up for NBC Boston's newsletters.\n\n[The live stream above is scheduled to start at 9:45 a.m. ET. If you don't see a video player at that time, please refresh the page.\n\nBoeing aims to launch its first Starliner flight with astronauts on Wednesday, in the latest attempt to fly the long-delayed spacecraft.\n\nThe launch is scheduled for 10:52 a.m. ET from Cape Canaveral, Florida. Two NASA astronauts will be aboard the Starliner capsule, which will be carried by United Launch Alliance's Atlas V rocket to the International Space Station.\n\nWednesday is the latest in a series of attempts to launch the mission, which is known as the Boeing crew flight test. On Saturday, a launch attempt was called off in the final minutes of the countdown due to a problem with one of the computer's that provides ground support to the rocket. In early May, another attempt was called off due to an issue detected with the rocket itself.\n\nIf the launch is postponed again, Boeing has a backup opportunity scheduled for Thursday.\n\nSign up here to receive weekly editions of CNBC's Investing in Space newsletter.\n\nUnited Launch Alliance - or ULA, a joint venture of Boeing and Lockheed Martin - replaced the rocket's problematic valve after the May attempt and replaced a faulty part in the ground infrastructure computer after Saturday's attempt.\n\nIn between the two previous launch attempts, NASA and Boeing found a \"small\" helium leak in Starliner, causing the agency and company to perform another series of assessments. After analysis, NASA and Boeing believe the source of the leak is in the spacecraft's helium propulsion system. But officials said after an investigation that the leak is \"stable\" and \"not a safety of flight issue.\"\n\nStarliner's crew debut has been delayed by years, while SpaceX's competing Dragon capsule has flown astronauts for NASA regularly since 2020 under the agency's Commercial Crew program. To date, Boeing has eaten $1.5 billion in costs due to Starliner setbacks and nearly $5 billion of NASA development funds.\n\nThe spacecraft was once seen as a competitor to SpaceX's Dragon. However, various setbacks and delays have steadily slipped Starliner into a backup position for NASA, with the agency taking the rare step of reassigning astronauts off the first Boeing crew flights in 2021. Boeing is under contract to fly six operational Starliner missions to the ISS.\n\nWednesday's crew flight test represents the final major step before receiving NASA certification to begin regular missions.\n\nButch Wilmore and Suni Williams are flying on Starliner, with the former serving as the spacecraft's commander and the latter as its pilot.\n\nWilmore joined NASA in 2000 and has flown to space twice previously on the Space Shuttle and Russia's Soyuz. Before NASA, Wilmore was a U.S. Navy pilot.\n\nWilliams was selected by NASA in 1998 and has also flown to space twice before, on the Space Shuttle and then the Soyuz. Williams was also a Navy pilot, like Wilmore, before joining the space agency.\n\nStarliner launches on ULA's Atlas V. The rocket debuted in 2002, and the Starliner crew flight test represents its 100th launch.\n\nThe capsule itself is built to carry as many as four NASA astronauts per flight and more than 200 pounds of research and cargo. The spacecraft lands using a parachute and airbag system. Starliner is reusable, with each capsule designed to fly as many as 10 missions.\n\nBoeing's crew flight test aims to certify the Starliner system as capable of carrying NASA astronauts to and from the ISS.\n\nIf Starliner launches on Wednesday, it will fly in space for about 25 hours before a planned docking with the International Space Station at 12:15 p.m. on Thursday. The astronauts will then spend about a week on the ISS, focused on testing Starliner, before returning to Earth.", "source": {"uri": "nbcboston.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC Boston"}, {"uri": "8163036540", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "14:03:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T14:03:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T14:03:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.nbcmiami.com/news/business/money-report/boeing-starliner-to-make-another-attempt-at-launching-nasa-astronauts/3329123/", "title": "Boeing Starliner to make another attempt at launching NASA astronauts", "body": "Starliner's crew debut has been delayed by years, while SpaceX's competing Dragon capsule has flown astronauts for NASA regularly since 2020.\n\n[The live stream above is scheduled to start at 9:45 a.m. ET. If you don't see a video player at that time, please refresh the page.\n\nBoeing aims to launch its first Starliner flight with astronauts on Wednesday, in the latest attempt to fly the long-delayed spacecraft.\n\nThe launch is scheduled for 10:52 a.m. ET from Cape Canaveral, Florida. Two NASA astronauts will be aboard the Starliner capsule, which will be carried by United Launch Alliance's Atlas V rocket to the International Space Station.\n\nWednesday is the latest in a series of attempts to launch the mission, which is known as the Boeing crew flight test. On Saturday, a launch attempt was called off in the final minutes of the countdown due to a problem with one of the computer's that provides ground support to the rocket. In early May, another attempt was called off due to an issue detected with the rocket itself.\n\nIf the launch is postponed again, Boeing has a backup opportunity scheduled for Thursday.\n\nSign up here to receive weekly editions of CNBC's Investing in Space newsletter.\n\nUnited Launch Alliance - or ULA, a joint venture of Boeing and Lockheed Martin - replaced the rocket's problematic valve after the May attempt and replaced a faulty part in the ground infrastructure computer after Saturday's attempt.\n\nIn between the two previous launch attempts, NASA and Boeing found a \"small\" helium leak in Starliner, causing the agency and company to perform another series of assessments. After analysis, NASA and Boeing believe the source of the leak is in the spacecraft's helium propulsion system. But officials said after an investigation that the leak is \"stable\" and \"not a safety of flight issue.\"\n\nStarliner's crew debut has been delayed by years, while SpaceX's competing Dragon capsule has flown astronauts for NASA regularly since 2020 under the agency's Commercial Crew program. To date, Boeing has eaten $1.5 billion in costs due to Starliner setbacks and nearly $5 billion of NASA development funds.\n\nThe spacecraft was once seen as a competitor to SpaceX's Dragon. However, various setbacks and delays have steadily slipped Starliner into a backup position for NASA, with the agency taking the rare step of reassigning astronauts off the first Boeing crew flights in 2021. Boeing is under contract to fly six operational Starliner missions to the ISS.\n\nWednesday's crew flight test represents the final major step before receiving NASA certification to begin regular missions.\n\nButch Wilmore and Suni Williams are flying on Starliner, with the former serving as the spacecraft's commander and the latter as its pilot.\n\nWilmore joined NASA in 2000 and has flown to space twice previously on the Space Shuttle and Russia's Soyuz. Before NASA, Wilmore was a U.S. Navy pilot.\n\nWilliams was selected by NASA in 1998 and has also flown to space twice before, on the Space Shuttle and then the Soyuz. Williams was also a Navy pilot, like Wilmore, before joining the space agency.\n\nStarliner launches on ULA's Atlas V. The rocket debuted in 2002, and the Starliner crew flight test represents its 100th launch.\n\nThe capsule itself is built to carry as many as four NASA astronauts per flight and more than 200 pounds of research and cargo. The spacecraft lands using a parachute and airbag system. Starliner is reusable, with each capsule designed to fly as many as 10 missions.\n\nBoeing's crew flight test aims to certify the Starliner system as capable of carrying NASA astronauts to and from the ISS.\n\nIf Starliner launches on Wednesday, it will fly in space for about 25 hours before a planned docking with the International Space Station at 12:15 p.m. on Thursday. The astronauts will then spend about a week on the ISS, focused on testing Starliner, before returning to Earth.", "source": {"uri": "nbcmiami.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC 6 South {"uri": "2024-06-380110645", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "20:53:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T20:53:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T20:08:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://queondamagazine.com/boeing-launches-new-capsule-on-1st-test-flight-with-nasa-astronauts-toward-space-station/", "title": "Boeing launches new capsule on 1st test flight with NASA astronauts toward space station \" \u00a1Que Onda Magazine!", "body": "CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. -- Boeing launched astronauts for the first time Wednesday, belatedly joining SpaceX as a second taxi service for NASA.\n\nA pair of NASA test pilots blasted off aboard Boeing's Starliner capsule for the International Space Station, the first to fly the new spacecraft.\n\nThe trip by Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams was expected to take 25 hours, with an arrival Thursday. They will spend just over a week at the orbiting lab before climbing back into Starliner for a remote desert touchdown in the western U.S. on June 14.\n\nYears late because of spacecraft flaws, Starliner's crew debut comes as the company struggles with unrelated safety issues on its airplane side.\n\nRELATED: Boeing's Starliner launch scrubbed for 3rd time\n\nWilmore and Williams - retired Navy captains and former space station residents - stressed repeatedly before the launch that they had full confidence in Boeing's ability to get it right with this test flight. Crippled by bad software, Starliner's initial test flight in 2019 without a crew had to be repeated before NASA would let its astronauts strap in. The 2022 do-over went much better, but parachute problems later cropped up and flammable tape had to be removed from the capsule.\n\nWednesday's launch was the third attempt with astronauts since early May, coming after a pair of rocket-related problems, most recently last weekend. A small helium leak in the spacecraft's propulsion system also caused delays, but managers decided the leak was manageable and not a safety issue.\n\n\"I know it's been a long road to get here,\" NASA's commercial crew program manager Steve Stich said before the weekend delay.\n\nThe flight, if successful, will rival SpaceX's prolific Crew Dragon capsule and expand American options for ferrying astronauts to ISS.\n\nBoeing was hired alongside Elon Musk's SpaceX a decade ago to ferry NASA's astronauts to and from the space station. The space agency wanted two competing U.S. companies for the job in the wake of the space shuttles' retirement, paying $4.2 billion to Boeing and just over half that to SpaceX, which refashioned the capsule it was using to deliver station supplies.\n\nSpaceX launched astronauts into orbit in 2020, becoming the first private business to achieve what only three countries - Russia, the U.S. and China - had mastered. It has taken nine crews to the space station for NASA and three private groups for a Houston company that charters flights.\n\nThe liftoff from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station was the 100th of an Atlas V for rocket maker United Launch Alliance. It was the first ride for astronauts on an Atlas rocket since John Glenn's Mercury era more than 60 years ago; the rocket usually launches satellites and other spacecraft.\n\nDespite the Atlas V's perfect record, the human presence cranked up the tension for the scores of NASA and Boeing employees gathered at Cape Canaveral and Mission Control in Houston.\n\nBoeing's Starliner and SpaceX's Dragon are designed to be fully autonomous and reusable. Wilmore and Williams occasionally will take manual control of Starliner on their way to the space station, to check out its systems.\n\nIf the mission goes well, NASA will alternate between SpaceX and Boeing for taxi flights, beginning next year. The backup pilot for this test flight, Mike Fincke, will strap in for Starliner's next trip.\n\n\"When you have a new spacecraft, you need to learn all about it and this has been a great exercise,\" Fincke told reporters late last week.\n\nThis story comes from our news partner ABC13 Houston.", "source": {"uri": "queondamagazine.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "\u00a1Que Onda Magazine!"}, {"uri": "2024-06-380013581", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "18:36:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T18:36:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T18:26:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://www.republicworld.com/science/boeing-launches-nasa-astronauts-for-first-time-after-years-of-delays", "title": "Boeing Launches NASA Astronauts for First Time After Years of Delays", "body": "Cape Canaveral: Boeing launched astronauts for the first time Wednesday, belatedly joining SpaceX as a second taxi service for NASA.\n\nA pair of NASA test pilots blasted off aboard Boeing's Starliner capsule for the International Space Station, the first to fly the new spacecraft.\n\nThe trip by Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams was expected to take 25 hours, with an arrival Thursday. They will spend just over a week at the orbiting lab before climbing back into Starliner for a remote desert touchdown in the western U.S. on June 14.\n\n\"Let's get going!\" Wilmore called out a few minutes before liftoff.\n\nHalf an hour later, he and Williams were safely in orbit and giving chase to the space station. Back at Cape Canaveral, the relieved launch controllers stood and applauded. After all the trouble leading up to Wednesday's launch, including two scrapped countdowns, everything went smoothly before and during liftoff, prompting congratulations from SpaceX's Elon Musk and others.\n\n\"Today it all lined up,\" said Boeing program manager Mark Nappi.\n\nBoeing's Starliner capsule, atop an Atlas V rocket, lifts off from launch pad at Space Launch Complex 41 Wednesday, June 5, 2024, in Cape Canaveral, Fla. NASA astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams are headed to the International Space Station. (AP Photo/Chris O'Meara)\n\nYears late because of spacecraft flaws, Starliner's crew debut comes as the company struggles with unrelated safety issues on its airplane side.\n\nWilmore and Williams -- retired Navy captains and former space station residents -- stressed repeatedly before the launch that they had full confidence in Boeing's ability to get it right with this test flight. Crippled by bad software, Starliner's initial test flight in 2019 without a crew had to be repeated before NASA would let its astronauts strap in. The 2022 do-over went much better, but parachute problems later cropped up and flammable tape had to be removed from the capsule.\n\nWednesday's launch was the third attempt with astronauts since early May, coming after a pair of rocket-related problems, most recently last weekend. A small helium leak in the spacecraft's propulsion system also caused delays, but remained extremely low and manageable.\n\n\"It's just a tough endeavor to get to flight and huge kudos to the entire team for getting there,\" said Steve Stich, NASA's commercial crew program manager.\n\nBoeing was hired alongside Elon Musk's SpaceX a decade ago to ferry NASA's astronauts to and from the space station. The space agency wanted two competing U.S. companies for the job in the wake of the space shuttles' retirement, paying $4.2 billion to Boeing and just over half that to SpaceX, which refashioned the capsule it was using to deliver station supplies.\n\nSpaceX launched astronauts into orbit in 2020, becoming the first private business to achieve what only three countries -- Russia, the U.S. and China -- had mastered. It has taken nine crews to the space station for NASA and three private groups for a Houston company that charters flights.\n\nBoeing's Starliner capsule atop an Atlas V rocket lifts off from Space Launch Complex 41 at the Cape Canaveral Space Force Station on a mission to the International Space Station, Wednesday, June 5, 2024, in Cape Canaveral, Fla. (AP Photo/John Raoux)\n\nThe liftoff from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station was the 100th of an Atlas V for rocket maker United Launch Alliance. It was the first ride for astronauts on an Atlas rocket since John Glenn's Mercury era more than 60 years ago; the rocket usually launches satellites and other spacecraft.\n\nDespite the Atlas V's perfect record, the human presence cranked up the tension for the scores of NASA and Boeing employees gathered at Cape Canaveral and Mission Control in Houston.\n\nBoeing's Starliner and SpaceX's Dragon are designed to be fully autonomous and reusable. Wilmore and Williams occasionally will take manual control of Starliner on their way to the space station, to check out its systems. The only snag early in the flight involved the capsule's cooling system. More water was used than expected before the radiators took over in orbit. The tank will be refilled before the ride home.\n\nIf the mission goes well, NASA will alternate between SpaceX and Boeing for taxi flights, beginning next year. The backup pilot for this test flight, Mike Fincke, will strap in for Starliner's next trip.\n\n\"This is exciting. We built up to this moment for years and years, and it finally happened,\" Fincke said from neighboring Kennedy Space Center. \"I feel like the whole planet was cheering for them.\"", "source": {"uri": "2024-06-378686202", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "16:54:25", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T16:54:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T16:45:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8196078538894653, "url": "https://eu.tennessean.com/story/news/2024/06/04/nasa-boeing-starliner-launch-livestream-launch-june-5-2024/73958917007/", "title": "Try, try again: Boeing Starliner launch with Tennessee co-pilot slated for Wednesday", "body": "The rocket was set to bring two NASA astronauts to the international space station for the first time, but was called off four minutes before launch.\n\nCould the third time be the charm for the NASA and Boeing Starliner launch on Wednesday?\n\nWith just under four minutes left on the countdown, the second attempt to launch Boeing's manned Starliner was scrubbed when the rocket's computer initiated a hold, NASA stated. The next launch attempt window NASA will aim for is Wednesday.\n\nTwo experienced astronauts, including a Tennessee native, are part of an even higher stakes demonstration after the scrapping of the last two mission. This is the final demonstration before the spacecraft can be approved for routine trips to orbit.\n\nBarry \"Butch\" Wilmore, a Mt. Juliet High School and Tennessee Tech graduate, will be in the cockpit along with Sunita \"Suni\" Williams, for the CST-100 Starliner test mission Wednesday in Florida. Wilmore and Williams will be the first crew on board for a Starliner orbital flight test.\n\nWhen is the Boeing Starliner's third launch attempt?\n\nAccording to Space.com, the mission is set to launch at 10:52 a.m. ET/ 9:52 a.m. CT Wednesday from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station, on Florida's Space Coast.\n\nThe Starliner and the two astronauts will be atop a ULA Atlas V rocket.\n\nWhy were the first two Starliner launches scrubbed?\n\nThe first launch attempt was supposed to take place almost a month ago on May 6 but was scrubbed due to a stuck valve on the rocket launching Starliner. It was replaced, but a small helium leak on one of Starliner's thrusters was also discovered by engineers. The next attempt wouldn't happen until June.\n\nOn Saturday, June 1, Starliner was expected to make the journey to the International Space Station but the launch attempt was stopped \"due to the computer ground launch sequencer not loading into the correct operational configuration after proceeding into terminal count,\" said a post from NASA Commercial Crew on X, the social network formerly known as Twitter.\n\nWhat is Boeing's Starliner purpose?\n\nBoeing's Starliner is intended to be a vehicle to ferry astronauts to and from the space station. The Starliner's design is meant to accommodate no more than seven passengers for low-Earth orbit missions. NASA intends for the capsule to carry only four astronauts along with a mix of cargo and other scientific instruments to and from the International Space Station.\n\nThis launch is one of several that NASA has had after partnering with private industry to help continue programs for space travel and exploration.\n\nBoeing received a $4.2 billion contract from NASA in 2014, but didn't launch its first unmanned mission in 2019. The Starliner project is years behind competitors like Elon Musk's SpaceX program and is also over budget with the project. Boeing estimates the project has cost the private company $1 billion in losses, reports NPR.\n\nHow to watch the Boeing Starliner launch with NASA on Wednesday\n\nAs of Monday, June 3, a news release states the NASA livestream for the next attempt will take place the morning of the launch as the countdown milestones occur.\n\nFind NASA's livestream here.\n\nWho are the NASA astronauts on Boeing's Starliner?\n\nBoth Williams and Wilmore are experienced pilots with the Navy and have flown in space twice, according to Florida Today, a USA TODAY Network publication. {"uri": "8163298531", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "16:59:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T16:59:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T16:58:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/technology/2973082-boeing-starliner-rockets-into-space-a-new-era-in-space-travel", "title": "Boeing Starliner Rockets into Space: A New Era in Space Travel | Technology", "body": "Boeing's Starliner capsule carried its first astronauts to space, marking a key milestone in its rivalry with SpaceX. The launch, conducted from Cape Canaveral, was successful despite previous delays. Astronauts Barry Wilmore and Sunita Williams are en route to the ISS, showcasing Boeing's potential in space travel.\n\nBoeing's new Starliner capsule flew its first crew of astronauts to space on Wednesday from Florida in a much-delayed test mission to the International Space Station, a milestone in the aerospace giant's ambitions to step up its competition with Elon Musk's SpaceX. The CST-100 Starliner, with astronauts Barry \"Butch\" Wilmore and Sunita \"Suni\" Williams aboard, lifted off from the Cape Canaveral Space Force Station, strapped to an Atlas V rocket furnished and flown by the Boeing-Lockheed Martin joint venture United Launch Alliance (ULA).\n\nThe gumdrop-shaped capsule and its crew was headed for a rendezvous with the International Space Station (ISS) following years of technical problems, delays and a successful 2022 test mission to the orbital laboratory without astronauts aboard. On Wednesday, the Atlas V's engines thundered to life in flaming clouds of exhaust and coolant-water vapor as the spacecraft roared off its launch pad into sunny skies from Florida's Atlantic Coast.\n\nThe rocket's upper stage separated from its lower section about four minutes into flight, followed by Starliner's separation from the second stage. Now on its own, the spacecraft fired onboard thrusters to start pushing itself into orbit, mission managers said, a process that starts its 24-hour catch-up journey with the ISS, which orbits some 250 miles (400 km) above Earth. Starliner will need to execute precise maneuvers to dock with the ISS as planned on Thursday, demonstrate it can stay docked for about eight days, then safely return the two astronauts to Earth.\n\nBoeing intends for Starliner to compete with SpaceX's Crew Dragon capsule, which since 2020 has been NASA's only vehicle for sending ISS crew members to orbit from U.S. soil. Mark Nappi, Boeing's Starliner program chief, told a news conference that tens of thousands of things have to go right during Starliner's launch, and that on Wednesday \"it all lined up.\"\n\n\"We had just a perfect countdown and launch. ... We're on orbit with Butch and Suni, it's been a longtime coming. And we're really, really proud,\" Nappi said. Boeing shares were up less than 1% in early afternoon trade.\n\n\"Starliner ascends to the heavens,\" NASA chief Bill Nelson wrote on social media, congratulating Boeing, ULA and the U.S. space agency. Nelson called the launch \"a milestone achievement for the future of spaceflight. Butch and Suni - safe travels through the stars. See you back home.\"\n\nLast-minute issues had nixed the Starliner's first two crewed launch attempts. A May 6 countdown was halted two hours before liftoff over three issues that required weeks of extra scrutiny. Another try last Saturday was halted less than four minutes before liftoff because of a launchpad computer glitch. The inaugural crew for the seven-seat Starliner includes two veteran NASA astronauts in Wilmore, 61, a retired U.S. Navy captain and fighter pilot, and Williams, 58, a former Navy helicopter test pilot with experience flying more than 30 different aircraft.\n\nThey have spent a combined 500 days in space over the course of two ISS missions each. Wilmore is the designated commander for the flight, with Williams in the pilot seat. BOEING AMBITIONS\n\nBoeing, with its commercial airplane operations rocked by a series of crises involving its 737 MAX jetliners, needs a win in space for its Starliner venture, already several years behind schedule and more than $1.5 billion over budget. The longtime NASA contractor has built modules for the decades-old ISS and rockets designed to loft astronauts toward the moon. But Boeing never before built its own operational spacecraft, a feat complicated by years of software issues, technical glitches and management shakeups on the Starliner program.\n\nMeanwhile, SpaceX's Crew Dragon has become a dependable taxi to orbit for NASA. That capsule and Starliner are among the first in a new generation of privately built spacecraft - seeded with NASA funding - designed to fly astronauts to low-Earth orbit and the moon under the agency's Artemis program. Starliner would compete head-to-head with SpaceX's Crew Dragon capsule, which since 2020 has been NASA's only vehicle for sending ISS crew members to orbit from U.S. soil.\n\n\"Congratulations on a successful launch,\" Musk wrote on social media. Although Starliner is designed to fly autonomously, the crew can assume control of it if necessary. The test flight calls for Wilmore and Williams to practice maneuvering manually en route to ISS.\n\nWilmore and Williams are due to join ISS's current seven resident crew members before riding the capsule back to Earth for a parachute and airbag-assisted landing in the U.S. Desert Southwest - a first for a crewed NASA mission. Getting Starliner to this point has been a fraught process for Boeing under its $4.2 billion fixed-priced contract with NASA, which wants the redundancy of two different U.S. rides to the ISS, an outpost expected to retire around 2030.\n\nMeanwhile, SpaceX's fourth test launch of its Starship rocket system, another step in its quest to build a reusable satellite launcher and moon lander, is due for liftoff on Thursday from Texas.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Devdiscourse"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cape_Canaveral_Space_Force_Station", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Cape Canaveral Space Force Station"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_Starliner", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Boeing Starliner"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barry_E._Wilmore", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Barry E. {"uri": "8161886697", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "22:56:54", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T22:56:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T22:49:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/tech/boeing-starliners-first-astronaut-mission-220615999.html", "title": "Boeing Starliner's first astronaut mission scheduled to launch Wednesday", "body": "June 4 (UPI) -- After several scrubbed liftoffs, Boeing's first Starliner crewed mission will try again Wednesday to launch NASA astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams on a critical, week-long test flight to the International Space Station.\n\nNASA and Boeing confirmed Monday that the Starliner capsule, United Launch Alliance Atlas V rocket and ground support equipment are in good shape and ready for the next launch attempt, which is scheduled for 10:52 a.m. EDT from Launch Complex 41 at Florida's Cape Canaveral Space Force Station.\n\n\"Less than 24 hours until the agency's next Boeing Space crew flight test launch attempt!\" NASA wrote Tuesday in a post on X. \"Weather officials predict 90% favorable weather for liftoff.\"\n\nStarliner and its crew have seen two scrubbed launches. A failed power distribution source at SLC-41 halted Saturday's launch attempt. As ground crews changed out and tested the system Sunday, Wilmore, 61, and Williams, 58, continued preparations for the mission as they remained quarantined at adjacent Kennedy Space Center.\n\n\"The ULA team identified an issue with a single ground power supply within one of the three redundant chassis that provides power to a subset of computer cards controlling various system functions, including the card responsible for the stable replenishment topping valves for the Centaur upper stage. All three of these chassis are required to enter the terminal phase of the launch countdown to ensure crew safety,\" NASA said in a statement.\n\n\"I really appreciate all the work by the NASA, Boeing and ULA teams over the last week,\" said Steve Stich, manager of NASA's Commercial Crew Program. \"In particular, the ULA team worked really hard to quickly learn more about these issues, kept our NASA and Boeing teams informed and protected for this next attempt. We will continue to take it one step at a time.\"\n\nLast month, the mission to certify Starliner for future manned missions was scrubbed 2 hours before launch over concerns about an oxygen relief valve. The noise heard May 6 turned out to be a mechanical valve that vents gas, which \"every now and then will flutter or buzz,\" according to Tory Bruno, ULA's chief executive officer.\n\nOnce Starliner successfully launches, the capsule will break away from the Atlas V rocket within the first 24 hours and fire its own engines to travel to the space station.\n\nWilmore and Williams, who are U.S. Navy-trained test pilots and helped develop the Starliner capsule, will use the mission to make sure all systems on board work as planned so that the spacecraft can be certified for future manned missions.\n\nStarliner will take Wilmore and Williams to the forward-facing port of the space station's Harmony module at approximately 12:15 p.m. Thursday.\n\nThe astronauts will remain at the space station for about a week to test the Starliner spacecraft in preparation for certification, which could put Boeing in direct competition with SpaceX and its commercial flight program.\n\nWilmore and Williams will return to Earth 10 days after launch in the same capsule, which is to parachute to a landing in the southwestern United States.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8163321465", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "17:16:50", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T17:16:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T17:15:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.gulf-times.com/article/684165/international/uslatin-america/boeings-starliner-spacecraft-sends-first-astronaut-crew-to-orbit", "title": "Boeing's Starliner spacecraft sends first astronaut crew to orbit", "body": "Boeing's new Starliner capsule flew its first crew of astronauts to space on Wednesday from Florida in a much-delayed test mission to the International Space Station, a milestone in the aerospace giant's ambitions to step up its competition with Elon Musk's SpaceX.\n\nThe CST-100 Starliner, with astronauts Barry \"Butch\" Wilmore and Sunita \"Suni\" Williams aboard, lifted off from the Cape Canaveral Space Force Station, strapped to an Atlas V rocket furnished and flown by the Boeing-Lockheed Martin joint venture United Launch Alliance (ULA).\n\nThe gumdrop-shaped capsule and its crew was headed for a rendezvous with the International Space Station (ISS) following years of technical problems, delays and a successful 2022 test mission to the orbital laboratory without astronauts aboard.\n\nOn Wednesday, the Atlas V's engines thundered to life in flaming clouds of exhaust and coolant-water vapor as the spacecraft roared off its launch pad into sunny skies from Florida's Atlantic Coast.\n\nThe rocket's upper stage separated from its lower section about four minutes into flight, followed by Starliner's separation from the second stage. Now on its own, the spacecraft fired onboard thrusters to start pushing itself into orbit, mission managers said, a process that starts its 24-hour catch-up journey with the ISS, which orbits some 250 miles (400 km) above Earth.\n\nStarliner will need to execute precise maneuvers to dock with the ISS as planned on Thursday, demonstrate it can stay docked for about eight days, then safely return the two astronauts to Earth.\n\nBoeing intends for Starliner to compete with SpaceX's Crew Dragon capsule, which since 2020 has been NASA's only vehicle for sending ISS crew members to orbit from US soil.\n\nMark Nappi, Boeing's Starliner program chief, told a news conference that tens of thousands of things have to go right during Starliner's launch, and that on Wednesday \"it all lined up.\"\n\n\"We had just a perfect countdown and launch. ... We're on orbit with Butch and Suni, it's been a longtime coming. And we're really, really proud,\" Nappi said.\n\nBoeing shares were up less than 1% in early afternoon trade.\n\n\"Starliner ascends to the heavens,\" NASA chief Bill Nelson wrote on social media, congratulating Boeing, ULA and the US space agency.\n\nNelson called the launch \"a milestone achievement for the future of spaceflight. Butch and Suni - safe travels through the stars. See you back home.\"\n\nLast-minute issues had nixed the Starliner's first two crewed launch attempts. A May 6 countdown was halted two hours before liftoff over three issues that required weeks of extra scrutiny. Another try last Saturday was halted less than four minutes before liftoff because of a launchpad computer glitch.\n\nThe inaugural crew for the seven-seat Starliner includes two veteran NASA astronauts in Wilmore, 61, a retired US Navy captain and fighter pilot, and Williams, 58, a former Navy helicopter test pilot with experience flying more than 30 different aircraft.\n\nThey have spent a combined 500 days in space over the course of two ISS missions each. Wilmore is the designated commander for the flight, with Williams in the pilot seat.\n\nBoeing, with its commercial airplane operations rocked by a series of crises involving its 737 MAX jetliners, needs a win in space for its Starliner venture, already several years behind schedule and more than $1.5 billion over budget.\n\nThe longtime NASA contractor has built modules for the decades-old ISS and rockets designed to loft astronauts toward the moon. But Boeing never before built its own operational spacecraft, a feat complicated by years of software issues, technical glitches and management shakeups on the Starliner program.\n\nMeanwhile, SpaceX's Crew Dragon has become a dependable taxi to orbit for NASA. That capsule and Starliner are among the first in a new generation of privately built spacecraft - seeded with NASA funding - designed to fly astronauts to low-Earth orbit and the moon under the agency's Artemis program.\n\nStarliner would compete head-to-head with SpaceX's Crew Dragon capsule, which since 2020 has been NASA's only vehicle for sending ISS crew members to orbit from US soil.\n\n\"Congratulations on a successful launch,\" Musk wrote on social media.\n\nAlthough Starliner is designed to fly autonomously, the crew can assume control of it if necessary. The test flight calls for Wilmore and Williams to practice maneuvering manually en route to ISS.\n\nWilmore and Williams are due to join ISS's current seven resident crew members before riding the capsule back to Earth for a parachute and airbag-assisted landing in the US Desert Southwest - a first for a crewed NASA mission.\n\nGetting Starliner to this point has been a fraught process for Boeing under its $4.2 billion fixed-priced contract with NASA, which wants the redundancy of two different US rides to the ISS, an outpost expected to retire around 2030.\n\nMeanwhile, SpaceX's fourth test launch of its Starship rocket system, another step in its quest to build a reusable satellite launcher and moon lander, is due for liftoff on Thursday from Texas.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8161426295", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-04", "time": "15:59:39", "dateTime": "2024-06-04T15:59:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-04T15:59:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://scitechdaily.com/liftoff-looms-boeing-starliner-ready-for-launch/", "title": "Liftoff Looms: Boeing Starliner Ready for Launch", "body": "NASA and Boeing teams have confirmed the readiness of the Starliner spacecraft and ULA Atlas V rocket for a scheduled launch on June 5. The mission will transport astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams to the International Space Station for a one-week mission. Credit: Boeing\n\nReady for launch, NASA's Starliner mission aims to transport astronauts to the ISS on June 5, with all systems and weather conditions set to go.\n\nOn Monday, teams at NASA and Boeing confirmed that the company's Starliner spacecraft, ULA (United Launch Alliance) Atlas V rocket, and ground support equipment are healthy and ready for the next launch attempt. The first Starliner flight with NASA astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams, known as NASA's Boeing Crew Flight Test, is targeted to liftoff at 10:52 a.m. EDT Wednesday, June 5, to the International Space Station (ISS) for about a one week stay aboard the microgravity laboratory.\n\nWork at the launch pad at Space Launch Complex-41 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station in Florida was completed June 2 to change out and test a failed power distribution source that halted a launch attempt on June 1. The Starliner mission management team reviewed multiple aspects of the replacement and troubleshooting steps and polled \"go\" to proceed during a detailed session as they continue to prep the teams and hardware for the June 5 opportunity.\n\n\"I really appreciate all the work by the NASA, Boeing, and ULA teams over the last week,\" said Steve Stich, manager of NASA's Commercial Crew Program. \"In particular, the ULA team worked really hard to quickly learn more about these issues, keep our NASA and Boeing teams informed, and protect for this next attempt. We will continue to take it one step at a time.\"\n\nThe weather forecast continues to call for favorable conditions, with U.S. Space Force meteorologists from the 45th Weather Squadron predicting a 90% chance of acceptable conditions at launch time. The ascent corridor and onshore winds weather also is forecast to be acceptable in the unlikely case of an emergency abort during the launch.\n\nWilmore and Williams continue preparing for launch with proficiency training. {"uri": "2024-06-380021722", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "18:46:33", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T18:46:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T18:39:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.newshub.co.nz/home/world/2024/06/boeing-s-starliner-spacecraft-sends-first-astronaut-crew-to-orbit.html", "title": "Boeing's Starliner spacecraft sends first astronaut crew to orbit", "body": "Boeing's new Starliner capsule flew its first crew of astronauts to space on Wednesday from Florida in a much delayed test mission to the International Space Station (ISS), a milestone in the aerospace giant's ambitions to step up its competition with Elon Musk's SpaceX.\n\nThe CST-100 Starliner, with astronauts Barry \"Butch\" Wilmore and Sunita \"Suni\" Williams aboard, lifted off from the Cape Canaveral Space Force Station, strapped to an Atlas V rocket furnished and flown by the Boeing-Lockheed Martin joint venture United Launch Alliance (ULA). The gumdrop-shaped capsule and its crew were headed for a rendezvous with the ISS following years of technical problems, delays and a successful 2022 test mission to the orbital laboratory without astronauts aboard.\n\nOn Wednesday, the Atlas V's engines thundered to life in flaming clouds of exhaust and coolant-water vapor as the spacecraft roared off its launch pad into sunny skies from Florida's Atlantic Coast.\n\nThe rocket's upper stage separated from its lower section about four minutes into flight, followed by Starliner's separation from the second stage. Now on its own, the spacecraft fired onboard thrusters to start pushing itself into orbit, mission managers said, a process that starts its 24-hour catch-up journey with the ISS, which orbits some 400km above Earth.\n\nStarliner will need to execute precise maneuvers to dock with the ISS as planned on Thursday, demonstrate it can stay docked for about eight days, then safely return the two astronauts to Earth.\n\nBoeing intends for Starliner to compete with SpaceX's Crew Dragon capsule, which since 2020 has been NASA's only vehicle for sending ISS crew members to orbit from US soil.\n\nMark Nappi, Boeing's Starliner program chief, told a news conference tens of thousands of things must go right during Starliner's launch, and on Wednesday \"it all lined up.\"\n\n\"We had just a perfect countdown and launch... We're on orbit with Butch and Suni, it's been a longtime coming. And we're really... proud,\" Nappi said.\n\nBoeing shares were up less than 1 percent in early afternoon trade.\n\n\"Starliner ascends to the heavens,\" NASA chief Bill Nelson wrote on social media, congratulating Boeing, ULA and the US space agency.\n\nNelson called the launch \"a milestone achievement for the future of spaceflight. Butch and Suni - safe travels through the stars.\n\n\"See you back home,\" Nelson said.\n\nLast-minute issues had nixed the Starliner's first two crewed launch attempts. A May 6 countdown was halted two hours before liftoff over three issues that required weeks of extra scrutiny.\n\nAnother attempt last Saturday was halted less than four minutes before liftoff because of a launchpad computer glitch.\n\nThe inaugural crew for the seven-seat Starliner includes two veteran NASA astronauts in Wilmore, 61, a retired US Navy captain and fighter pilot, and Williams, 58, a former Navy helicopter test pilot with experience flying more than 30 different aircraft.\n\nThey have spent 500 days in space over two ISS missions each. Wilmore is the designated commander for the flight, with Williams in the pilot seat.\n\nMore from Newshub\n\nBoeing calls off historic mission carrying two astronauts minutes before liftoff\n\n'Incredibly excited': Kiwi scientists to develop solar-powered aircraft with NASA\n\nBoeing ambitions\n\nWith its commercial airplane operations rocked by a series of crises involving its 737 MAX jetliners, Boeing needs a win in space for its Starliner venture, already several years behind schedule and more than $1.5 billion over budget.\n\nThe longtime NASA contractor has built modules for the decades-old ISS and rockets designed to loft astronauts toward the moon. But Boeing never built its own operational spacecraft, a feat complicated by years of software issues, technical glitches and management shakeups on the Starliner program.\n\nMeanwhile, SpaceX's Crew Dragon has become a dependable taxi to orbit for NASA. That capsule and Starliner are among the first in a new generation of privately built spacecraft - seeded with NASA funding - designed to fly astronauts to low-Earth orbit and the moon under the agency's Artemis program.\n\nStarliner would compete head-to-head with SpaceX's Crew Dragon capsule, which since 2020 has been NASA's only vehicle for sending ISS crew members to orbit from US soil.\n\n\"Congratulations on a successful launch,\" Musk wrote on social media.\n\nAlthough Starliner is designed to fly autonomously, the crew can assume control of it if necessary. The test flight calls for Wilmore and Williams to practice maneuvering manually en route to ISS.\n\nWilmore and Williams are due to join ISS's current seven resident crew members before riding the capsule back to Earth for a parachute and airbag-assisted landing in the US Desert Southwest - a first for a crewed NASA mission.\n\nGetting Starliner to this point has been a fraught process for Boeing under its $4.2 billion fixed-priced contract with NASA, which wants the redundancy of two different US rides to the ISS, an outpost expected to retire around 2030.\n\nMeanwhile, SpaceX's fourth test launch of its Starship rocket system, another step in its quest to build a reusable satellite launcher and moon lander, is due for liftoff on Thursday from Texas.", "source": {"uri":
