(AP) -- Boeing launched astronauts for the first time Wednesday, belatedly joining SpaceX as a second taxi service for NASA.\n\nA pair of NASA test pilots blasted off aboard Boeing's Starliner capsule for the International Space Station, the first to fly the new spacecraft.\n\nThe trip by Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams was expected to take 25 hours, with an arrival Thursday. They will spend just over a week at the orbiting lab before climbing back into Starliner for a remote desert touchdown in the western U.S. on June 14.\n\nYears late because of spacecraft flaws, Starliner's crew debut comes as the company struggles with unrelated safety issues on its airplane side.\n\nWilmore and Williams -- retired Navy captains and former space station residents -- stressed repeatedly before the launch that they had full confidence in Boeing's ability to get it right with this test flight. Crippled by bad software, Starliner's initial test flight in 2019 without a crew had to be repeated before NASA would let its astronauts strap in. The 2022 do-over went much better, but parachute problems later cropped up and flammable tape had to be removed from the capsule.\n\nWednesday's launch was the third attempt with astronauts since early May, coming after a pair of rocket-related problems, most recently last weekend. A small helium leak in the spacecraft's propulsion system also caused delays, but managers decided the leak was manageable and not a safety issue.\n\n\"I know it's been a long road to get here,\" NASA's commercial crew program manager Steve Stich said before the weekend delay.\n\nBoeing was hired alongside Elon Musk's SpaceX a decade ago to ferry NASA's astronauts to and from the space station. The space agency wanted two competing U.S. companies for the job in the wake of the space shuttles' retirement, paying $4.2 billion to Boeing and just over half that to SpaceX, which refashioned the capsule it was using to deliver station supplies.\n\nSpaceX launched astronauts into orbit in 2020, becoming the first private business to achieve what only three countries -- Russia, the U.S. and China -- had mastered. It has taken nine crews to the space station for NASA and three private groups for a Houston company that charters flights.\n\nThe liftoff from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station was the 100th of an Atlas V for rocket maker United Launch Alliance. It was the first ride for astronauts on an Atlas rocket since John Glenn's Mercury era more than 60 years ago; the rocket usually launches satellites and other spacecraft.\n\nDespite the Atlas V's perfect record, the human presence cranked up the tension for the scores of NASA and Boeing employees gathered at Cape Canaveral and Mission Control in Houston.\n\nBoeing's Starliner and SpaceX's Dragon are designed to be fully autonomous and reusable. Wilmore and Williams occasionally will take manual control of Starliner on their way to the space station, to check out its systems.\n\nIf the mission goes well, NASA will alternate between SpaceX and Boeing for taxi flights, beginning next year. The backup pilot for this test flight, Mike Fincke, will strap in for Starliner's next trip.\n\n\"When you have a new spacecraft, you need to learn all about it and this has been a great exercise,\" Fincke told reporters late last week.\n\nThe Associated Press Health and Science Department receives support from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute's Science and Educational Media Group. {"uri": "8163162685", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "15:24:08", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T15:24:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T15:23:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://lasvegassun.com/news/2024/jun/05/boeing-launches-nasa-astronauts-for-the-first-time/", "title": "Boeing launches NASA astronauts for the first time after years of delays", "body": "John Raoux / AP\n\nBoeing's Starliner capsule atop an Atlas V rocket lifts off from Space Launch Complex 41 at the Cape Canaveral Space Force Station on a mission to the International Space Station, Wednesday, June 5, 2024, in Cape Canaveral, Fla.\n\nBy Marcia Dunn, Associated Press\n\nWednesday, June 5, 2024 | 8:16 a.m.\n\nCAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. -- Boeing launched astronauts for the first time Wednesday, belatedly joining SpaceX as a second taxi service for NASA.\n\nA pair of NASA test pilots blasted off aboard Boeing's Starliner capsule for the International Space Station, the first to fly the new spacecraft.\n\nThe trip by Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams was expected to take 25 hours, with an arrival Thursday. They will spend just over a week at the orbiting lab before climbing back into Starliner for a remote desert touchdown in the western U.S. on June 14.\n\n\"Let's get going!\" Wilmore called out minutes before liftoff.\n\nYears late because of spacecraft flaws, Starliner's crew debut comes as the company struggles with unrelated safety issues on its airplane side.\n\nWilmore and Williams -- retired Navy captains and former space station residents -- stressed repeatedly before the launch that they had full confidence in Boeing's ability to get it right with this test flight. Crippled by bad software, Starliner's initial test flight in 2019 without a crew had to be repeated before NASA would let its astronauts strap in. The 2022 do-over went much better, but parachute problems later cropped up and flammable tape had to be removed from the capsule.\n\nWednesday's launch was the third attempt with astronauts since early May, coming after a pair of rocket-related problems, most recently last weekend. A small helium leak in the spacecraft's propulsion system also caused delays, but managers decided the leak was manageable and not a safety issue.\n\n\"I know it's been a long road to get here,\" NASA's commercial crew program manager Steve Stich said before the weekend delay.\n\nBoeing was hired alongside Elon Musk's SpaceX a decade ago to ferry NASA's astronauts to and from the space station. The space agency wanted two competing U.S. companies for the job in the wake of the space shuttles' retirement, paying $4.2 billion to Boeing and just over half that to SpaceX, which refashioned the capsule it was using to deliver station supplies.\n\nSpaceX launched astronauts into orbit in 2020, becoming the first private business to achieve what only three countries -- Russia, the U.S. and China -- had mastered. It has taken nine crews to the space station for NASA and three private groups for a Houston company that charters flights.\n\nThe liftoff from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station was the 100th of an Atlas V for rocket maker United Launch Alliance. It was the first ride for astronauts on an Atlas rocket since John Glenn's Mercury era more than 60 years ago; the rocket usually launches satellites and other spacecraft.\n\nDespite the Atlas V's perfect record, the human presence cranked up the tension for the scores of NASA and Boeing employees gathered at Cape Canaveral and Mission Control in Houston.\n\nBoeing's Starliner and SpaceX's Dragon are designed to be fully autonomous and reusable. Wilmore and Williams occasionally will take manual control of Starliner on their way to the space station, to check out its systems.\n\nIf the mission goes well, NASA will alternate between SpaceX and Boeing for taxi flights, beginning next year. The backup pilot for this test flight, Mike Fincke, will strap in for Starliner's next trip.\n\n\"When you have a new spacecraft, you need to learn all about it and this has been a great exercise,\" Fincke told reporters late last week.\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press Health and Science Department receives support from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute's Science and Educational Media Group. Crippled by bad software, Starliner's initial test flight in 2019 without a crew had to be repeated before NASA would let its astronauts strap in. The 2022 do-over went much better, but parachute problems later cropped up and flammable tape had to be removed from the capsule.\n\nWednesday's launch was the third attempt with astronauts since early May, coming after a pair of rocket-related problems, most recently last weekend. A small helium leak in the spacecraft's propulsion system also caused delays, but managers decided the leak was manageable and not a safety issue.\n\n\"I know it's been a long road to get here,\" NASA's commercial crew program manager Steve Stich said before the weekend delay.\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\nBoeing was hired alongside Elon Musk's SpaceX a decade ago to ferry NASA's astronauts to and from the space station. It was the first ride for astronauts on an Atlas rocket since John Glenn's Mercury era more than 60 years ago; the rocket usually launches satellites and other spacecraft.\n\nDespite the Atlas V's perfect record, the human presence cranked up the tension for the scores of NASA and Boeing employees gathered at Cape Canaveral and Mission Control in Houston.\n\nBoeing's Starliner and SpaceX's Dragon are designed to be fully autonomous and reusable. Wilmore and Williams occasionally will take manual control of Starliner on their way to the space station, to check out its systems.\n\nIf the mission goes well, NASA will alternate between SpaceX and Boeing for taxi flights, beginning next year. The backup pilot for this test flight, Mike Fincke, will strap in for Starliner's next trip.\n\n\"When you have a new spacecraft, you need to learn all about it and this has been a great exercise,\" Fincke told reporters late last week.\n\nThe Associated Press Health and Science Department receives support from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute's Science and Educational Media Group. "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9622079", "eventUri": "eng-9622079", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-06-14", "textStart": 538, "textEnd": {"uri": "8163132220", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "15:06:24", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T15:06:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T15:04:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/boeings-starliner-capsule-is-launched-from-florida-on-first-crewed-space-flight/article_11a2716b-aa76-52f7-8485-7df3b406ea25.html", "title": "Boeing's Starliner capsule is launched from Florida on first crewed space flight", "body": "NASA astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams walk at NASA's Kennedy Space Center, ahead of Boeing's Starliner-1 Crew Flight Test (CFT) mission on a United Launch Alliance Atlas V rocket to the International Space Station, in Cape Canaveral, Florida, U.S., June 5, 2024. REUTERS/Joe Skipper\n\nBy Joey Roulette\n\nWASHINGTON (Reuters) - Boeing's new Starliner astronaut capsule was launched from Florida on Wednesday in a much-delayed first test flight carrying a crew, a milestone in the aerospace giant's ambitions to step up its competition with Elon Musk's SpaceX.\n\nThe CST-100 Starliner, with two astronauts aboard, lifted off from the Cape Canaveral Space Force Station in Florida, strapped to an Atlas V rocket furnished and flown by the Boeing-Lockheed Martin joint venture United Launch Alliance (ULA).\n\nThe gumdrop-shaped capsule and its crew were headed for a rendezvous with the International Space Station (ISS), two years after the Starliner completed its first test voyage to the orbital laboratory without astronauts aboard. Docking maneuvers with crew will pose another test for Starliner, followed roughly a week later by the test of returning to Earth.\n\nBoeing intends for Starliner to compete with SpaceX's Crew Dragon capsule, which since 2020 has been NASA's only vehicle for sending ISS crew members to orbit from U.S. soil.\n\nLast-minute issues had nixed the Starliner's first two crewed launch attempts. A May 6 countdown was halted two hours before liftoff over three issues that required weeks of extra scrutiny. Another try last Saturday was halted less than four minutes before liftoff because of a glitch with a launchpad computer.\n\nOn Wednesday, the Atlas V's engines thundered to life in flaming clouds of exhaust and coolant-water vapor as the spacecraft roared off its launch pad into the sky from Florida's Atlantic Coast.\n\nThe single-engine Atlas V upper stage was expected to separate from the rocket's lower section about four minutes into flight and carry the Starliner farther into space, where it was due to separate from the upper stage about 15 minutes later.\n\nThe inaugural crew for the seven-seat Starliner includes two veteran NASA astronauts: Barry \"Butch\" Wilmore, 61, a retired U.S. Navy captain and fighter pilot, and Sunita \"Suni\" Williams, 58, a former Navy helicopter test pilot with experience flying more than 30 different aircraft.\n\nThey have spent a combined 500 days in space over the course of two ISS missions each. Wilmore is the designated commander for the flight, with Williams in the pilot seat. They are due to spend about a week at the ISS before returning to Earth.\n\nBoeing, with its commercial airplane operations rocked by a series of crises involving its 737 MAX jetliners, needs a win in space for its Starliner venture, already several years behind schedule and more than $1.5 billion over budget.\n\nStarliner two years ago completed its first test voyage to ISS and back without astronauts aboard.\n\nThe longtime NASA contractor has built modules for the decades-old ISS and rockets designed to loft astronauts toward the moon. But Boeing never before built its own operational spacecraft, a feat complicated by years of software issues, technical glitches and management shakeups on the Starliner program.\n\nMeanwhile, SpaceX's Crew Dragon has become a dependable taxi to orbit for NASA. That capsule and Starliner are among the first in a new generation of privately built spacecraft - seeded with NASA funding - designed to fly astronauts to low-Earth orbit and the moon under the U.S. space agency's Artemis program.\n\nStarliner would compete head-to-head with SpaceX's Crew Dragon capsule, which since 2020 has been NASA's only vehicle for sending ISS crew members to orbit from U.S. soil.\n\nIf all goes as planned, the capsule will arrive at ISS after a flight of about 24 hours and dock with the orbiting research outpost some 250 miles (400 km) above Earth.\n\nAlthough Starliner is designed to fly autonomously, the crew can assume control of the spacecraft if necessary. The test flight calls for Wilmore and Williams to practice maneuvering the vehicle manually en route to the space station, where it will remain docked for at least eight days before returning to Earth.\n\nWilmore and Williams are due to join ISS's current seven resident crew members before riding the capsule back to Earth for a parachute and airbag-assisted landing in the U.S. Desert Southwest - a first for a crewed NASA mission.\n\nGetting Starliner to this point has been a fraught process for Boeing under its $4.2 billion fixed-priced contract with NASA, which wants the redundancy of having two different U.S. rides to the ISS, an outpost expected to retire around 2030.\n\nMeanwhile, SpaceX's fourth test launch of its Starship rocket system, another chapter in its quest to build a reusable satellite launcher and moon lander, is due for liftoff on Thursday from Texas.\n\n(Reporting by Joey Roulette; Editing by Will Dunham)\n\nSign Up for Springs AM Update Your morning rundown of the latest news from Colorado Springs and around the country\n\nSign Up View all of our newsletters. {"uri": "2024-06-379829760", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "15:22:05", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T15:22:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T14:53:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.aol.com/delays-crewed-boeing-starliner-finally-145354269.html", "title": "After delays, crewed Boeing Starliner finally launches from Florida, bound for the ISS", "body": "After delays, crewed Boeing Starliner finally launches from Florida, bound for the ISS\n\nEric Lagatta, USA TODAY\n\nJune 5, 2024 at 4:53 PM\n\nTwo veteran NASA astronauts are finally bound for the International Space Station aboard Boeing's Starliner space capsule nearly a month after its initial planned launch was scrubbed multiple times.\n\nLaunching Wednesday from Florida, the inaugural crewed flight of Boeing's CST-100 Starliner is a critical demonstration for the aerospace company, which hopes to join Elon Musk's SpaceX as one of two companies making routine trips to orbit on NASA's behalf. The mission is the first crewed orbital test flight for Boeing following two previous demonstrations that were conducted with no astronauts on board.\n\nNASA, which provided live coverage of Saturday's launch, is expected to provide coverage of the landing as well.\n\nHere's what to know about the mission.\n\nLatest on Boeing Starliner after launching from Florida\n\nThe Starliner spacecraft was perched atop the Atlas V rocket when it launched at 10:52 a.m. ET Wednesday from the Kennedy Space Center in Cape Canaveral, Florida.\n\nWhat's next for Starliner?\n\nIf all goes to plan, Starliner will dock Thursday morning on the forward-facing port of the International Space Station's Harmony module. Once it reaches the space station in less than 24 hours, crew will spend a little more than a week testing the Starliner spacecraft and its subsystems before they board the capsule for a return trip to Earth.\n\nThe craft will land in the American Southwest using parachutes that will slow it down to 4 mph before inflating large airbags.\n\nWho is on board the Starliner?\n\nThe Starliner was designed to accommodate no more than seven passengers for missions to low-Earth orbit. For NASA, the capsule is intended to carry four astronauts along with a mix of cargo and other scientific instruments to and from the space station.\n\nThe two NASA astronauts on board the Starliner for Monday's launch are Barry \"Butch\" Wilmore and Sunita \"Suni\" Williams, both Navy test pilots who have ventured to space twice before.\n\nWhat happened on past Boeing test flights?\n\nDozens of software and engineering issues resulted in the failure of a previous attempt in 2019 to send an uncrewed Starliner to the ISS for a week.\n\nWhile it reached orbit, the capsule failed to reach the space station and instead returned to Earth, according to Florida Today, part of the USA TODAY Network. That mission raised questions and doubts about NASA's future with Boeing, which is scheduled to fly six crewed astronaut missions once it's certified as safe for flight, as reported by Reuters.\n\nThe follow-up flight test in 2022 met standards of docking to the space station and successfully landed, but not without the discovery of multiple issues as Boeing crews inspected the spacecraft later on, Florida Today reported.\n\nBoeing competes with SpaceX to make low-Earth orbit trips\n\nA successful mission would provide NASA with a second operational spacecraft to carry astronauts to the International Space Station.\n\nAs part of NASA's commercial crew program, Boeing was awarded $4.8 billion and SpaceX was awarded $3.1 billion in 2014 to develop their respective spacecrafts capable of making crewed scientific trips to low-Earth orbit, Florida Today reported.\n\nUnder NASA's more ambitious commercial lunar program, it's also paid SpaceX $2.9 billion to develop the first commercial human lander for the agency's Artemis moon missions and eventually trips to Mars.\n\nIn March, SpaceX had its most successful test yet of the Starship rocket needed to ferry astronauts to the lunar surface for the first time since the Apollo era. While in orbit, the Starship hit several key milestones and conducted a handful of in-flight tests that are a crucial step forward for it to be reliable and functional in time for Artemis III, slated for sometime in 2026.\n\nSpaceX, whose Dragon spacecraft flew its first human mission in 2020, recently saw its Crew-7 return to Earth after nearly 200 days aboard the International Space Station. The eighth crew comprised of three NASA astronauts and one cosmonaut launched March 3 and docked March 5 to await the arrival of Boeing's Starliner capsule.\n\nIf the mission is a success, NASA will begin the final process of certifying Starliner and its systems for crewed rotation missions to the space station, according to NASA.\n\nEric Lagatta covers breaking and trending news for USA TODAY. {"uri": "2024-06-379643939", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "12:42:22", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T12:42:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T10:19:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.aol.com/boeing-starliner-launch-livestream-watch-101937293.html", "title": "Boeing Starliner launch livestream: Watch latest attempt to send NASA astronauts to ISS", "body": "Boeing Starliner launch livestream: Watch latest attempt to send NASA astronauts to ISS\n\nEmily DeLetter, USA TODAY\n\nJune 5, 2024 at 12:19 PM\n\nAfter Saturday's launch for the Boeing Starliner spacecraft was scrubbed once again due to technological issues, a new launch date has been set for this week.\n\nUSA TODAY is providing live coverage of the Boeing Starliner launch, which is scheduled to liftoff Wednesday, June 5 at 10:52 a.m. ET from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station in Florida. You can watch the embedded video live at the top of the page or on USA TODAY's YouTube channel.\n\nLaunches are also streamed through NASA via NASA+, NASA Television, the NASA app, on YouTube or on the agency's website, with live coverage beginning at 6:45 a.m. ET.\n\nIf Wednesday's launch date does not go as planned, another possible launch date is Thursday, June 6.\n\nA year behind and over budget: Timeline shows Boeing Starliner struggles and scrubs\n\nThe Saturday launch was scrubbed about 4 minutes before liftoff. In a post on X, NASA said the launch attempt was stopped \"due to the computer ground launch sequencer not loading into the correct operational configuration after proceeding into terminal count.\"\n\nThis week's launch attempt follows several delays including a May 6 launch halted by a series of technical issues, an oxygen leak and a helium leak from the capsule's propulsion system.\n\nWhere is the Boeing Starliner going?\n\nThe Boeing Crew Flight Test is meant to carry two NASA astronauts: Barry \"Butch\" Wilmore and Sunita \"Suni\" Williams, both former Navy pilots, to and from the International Space Station.\n\nOnce on board, Wilmore and Williams will stay at the ISS for about a week to test the Starliner spacecraft and its subsystems.\n\nWhat is the Boeing Starliner?\n\nThe Starliner was designed to accommodate a crew of no more than seven for missions to low-Earth orbit. On NASA missions, the capsule would carry four astronauts along with a mix of cargo and other scientific instruments to and from the space station.\n\nIf Starliner is successful, NASA will begin the final process of certifying the spacecraft and its systems for crewed rotation missions to the space station, according to the U.S. space agency.\n\nBoeing was awarded $4.8 billion from NASA in 2014 to develop Starliner, a private industry-built vehicle that can ferry astronauts to and from the International Space Station.\n\nCompetitor, SpaceX, which recently saw the return of its eighth crew sent to the ISS, was awarded $3.1 billion to develop its respective spacecraft, as part of NASA's commercial crew program. NASA has also paid SpaceX $2.9 billion to develop the first commercial human lander for the agency's Artemis moon missions and eventually trips to Mars.\n\nContributing: Eric Lagatta, USA {"uri": "8163305007", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "17:06:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T17:06:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T17:03:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/boeing-and-centennials-ula-launches-nasa-astronauts-for-first-time-after-years-of-delays/article_7ab3f9a5-829b-5b7b-89bc-10c67edd35f1.html", "title": "Boeing and Centennial's ULA launches NASA astronauts for first time after years of delays", "body": "CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. (AP) -- Boeing and Centennial-based United Launch Alliance launched astronauts for the first time Wednesday, belatedly joining SpaceX as a second taxi service for NASA.\n\nA pair of NASA test pilots blasted off aboard Boeing's Starliner capsule for the International Space Station, the first to fly the new spacecraft.\n\nThe trip by Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams was expected to take 25 hours, with an arrival Thursday. They will spend just over a week at the orbiting lab before climbing back into Starliner for a remote desert touchdown in the western U.S. on June 14.\n\nYears late because of spacecraft flaws, Starliner's crew debut comes as the company struggles with unrelated safety issues on its airplane side.\n\nWilmore and Williams -- retired Navy captains and former space station residents -- stressed repeatedly before the launch that they had full confidence in Boeing's ability to get it right with this test flight. Crippled by bad software, Starliner's initial test flight in 2019 without a crew had to be repeated before NASA would let its astronauts strap in. The 2022 do-over went much better, but parachute problems later cropped up and flammable tape had to be removed from the capsule.\n\nWednesday's launch was the third attempt with astronauts since early May, coming after a pair of rocket-related problems, most recently last weekend. A small helium leak in the spacecraft's propulsion system also caused delays, but managers decided the leak was manageable and not a safety issue.\n\n\"I know it's been a long road to get here,\" NASA's commercial crew program manager Steve Stich said before the weekend delay.\n\nThe flight marks a major milestone for ULA -- the rocket manufacturing company set up up by Boeing and Lockheed Martin out of the Denver metro area -- with its first human launch in its 18-year history.\n\nThis test flight critical is for Boeing's Starliner to get NASA's certification to start routine crewed flights to the ISS and begin competing with SpaceX's Dragon.\n\nThese flights might not only go to the ISS but also to future space stations operated by private companies once the ISS shuts down.\n\nFeatured Local Savings\n\nBoeing was hired alongside Elon Musk's SpaceX a decade ago to ferry NASA's astronauts to and from the space station. The space agency wanted two competing U.S. companies for the job in the wake of the space shuttles' retirement, paying $4.2 billion to Boeing and just over half that to SpaceX, which refashioned the capsule it was using to deliver station supplies.\n\nSpaceX launched astronauts into orbit in 2020, becoming the first private business to achieve what only three countries -- Russia, the U.S. and China -- had mastered. It has taken nine crews to the space station for NASA and three private groups for a Houston company that charters flights.\n\nThe 172-foot-tall Atlas V rocket is from the same model of rockets from the 1950s that sent the first American, John Glenn, into Earth's orbit. It was originally designed by aerospace giant Lockheed Martin before ULA took over its manufacturing. The liftoff Wednesday from Cape Canaveral was the 100th Atlas V rocket to go into space.\n\nULA adjusted the rocket -- which shifted toward launching satellites and spacecraft for decades -- for the astronauts' safety. It has an emergency detection system that can automatically trigger an abort mission if an issue is detected.\n\nIt also brought back the \"Dual Engine Centaur,\" a fuel reserve of liquid hydrogen and oxygen, that boosts the rocket's thrust to have better control of the flight's trajectory and make sure its path allows for safely bringing astronauts back to earth in case of an emergency.\n\nIt was a feature used on all Atlas rockets between 1962 and 2000 and was brought back for the Starliner, according to ULA.\n\nDespite the Atlas V's record, the human presence cranked up the tension for the scores of NASA and Boeing employees gathered at Cape Canaveral and Mission Control in Houston.\n\nBoeing's Starliner and SpaceX's Dragon are designed to be fully autonomous and reusable. Wilmore and Williams occasionally will take manual control of Starliner on their way to the space station, to check out its systems.\n\nIf the mission goes well, NASA will alternate between SpaceX and Boeing for taxi flights, beginning next year. The backup pilot for this test flight, Mike Fincke, will strap in for Starliner's next trip.\n\n\"When you have a new spacecraft, you need to learn all about it and this has been a great exercise,\" Fincke told reporters late last week.\n\nThe Associated Press Health and Science Department receives support from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute's Science and Educational Media Group. The AP is solely responsible for all content.\n\nSign Up for Springs AM Update Your morning rundown of the latest news from Colorado Springs and around the country\n\nSign Up View all of our newsletters. {"uri": "8162640956", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "10:05:23", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T10:05:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T10:02:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/technology/2972503-boeings-starliner-a-third-attempt-to-space", "title": "Boeing's Starliner: A Third Attempt to Space | Technology", "body": "Boeing's Starliner spacecraft is set for a third attempt to fly astronauts to space. After delays due to technical issues, the CST-100 Starliner capsule, carrying two NASA astronauts, aims to compete with SpaceX's Crew Dragon. This mission is crucial for Boeing to secure certification for routine flights to the International Space Station.\n\nBoeing's Starliner spacecraft is set for a third attempt to fly astronauts to space for the first time on Wednesday, a much-delayed testing milestone in the aerospace giant's ambitions to step up its competition with Elon Musk's SpaceX.\n\nThe gumdrop-shaped CST-100 Starliner capsule, with two astronauts aboard, is due for liftoff at 10:52 a.m. ET (1452 GMT) from a launch pad at the Cape Canaveral Space Force Station in Florida, strapped to an Atlas V rocket from Boeing-Lockheed Martin joint venture United Launch Alliance (ULA). Boeing intends for Starliner to compete with SpaceX's Crew Dragon capsule, which since 2020 has been NASA's only vehicle for sending ISS crew members to orbit from U.S. soil. The capsule and its inaugural crew - NASA astronauts Barry \"Butch\" Wilmore and Sunita \"Suni\" Williams - will be bound for the International Space Station (ISS).\n\nLast-minute issues have pushed back Starliner's first two crewed launch attempts. A May 6 countdown was halted two hours before liftoff over three issues that required weeks of extra scrutiny. Another try last Saturday was halted less than four minutes before liftoff because of a glitch with a launchpad computer. ULA engineers replaced a power supply unit for that computer and put Starliner back on track for launch. The local weather is forecast to be 90% favorable for liftoff, according to U.S. Space Force launch weather analysts.\n\nThe crew is due to spend about a week at the space station before returning to Earth. Starliner two years ago completed its first test voyage to ISS and back without astronauts aboard. The mission is Boeing's final test before NASA can certify Starliner for routine astronaut flights that would make it the second U.S. ride to orbit.\n\nBoeing has faced years of Starliner development delays and more than $1.5 billion in cost overruns, as well as a series of crises involving the company's 737 MAX jetliners in its centerpiece aviation business. The longtime NASA contractor has built modules for the decades-old ISS and rockets designed to loft astronauts toward the moon. But Boeing never before built its own operational spacecraft, a feat complicated by years of software issues, technical glitches and management shakeups on the Starliner program.\n\nMeanwhile, SpaceX's Crew Dragon has become a dependable taxi to orbit for NASA. That capsule and Starliner are among the first in a new generation of privately built spacecraft - seeded with NASA funding - designed to fly astronauts to low-Earth orbit and the moon under the U.S. space agency's Artemis program. NASA has long sought two U.S. rides to the ISS in order to have a backup, in addition to the joint astronaut flights the agency conducts with Russia's Soyuz rocket.\n\nWilmore, 61, is a retired U.S. Navy captain and fighter pilot. Williams, 58, is a former Navy helicopter test pilot with experience flying more than 30 different aircraft. They have spent a combined 500 days in space during two ISS missions each. If the launch is postponed on Wednesday, Boeing could try again on Thursday. Any delay beyond Thursday could last weeks because of perishable items that would need to be replaced on Starliner and the rocket after sitting on the ground for a month. Other missions scheduled in Cape Canaveral and on the ISS could add to the delays.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "8163242034", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "16:19:10", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T16:19:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T16:17:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://agenparl.eu/2024/06/05/nasa-hq-news-liftoff-nasa-astronauts-pilot-first-starliner-crewed-test-to-station/", "title": "[NASA HQ News] LIFTOFF! NASA Astronauts Pilot First Starliner Crewed Test to Station - Agenparl", "body": "(AGENPARL) - mer 05 giugno 2024 LIFTOFF! NASA Astronauts Pilot First Starliner Crewed Test to Station\n\nJUN 05, 2024\n\nRELEASE 24-080\n\nA United Launch Alliance Atlas V rocket with Boeing's CST-100 Starliner spacecraft aboard launches from Space Launch Complex 41 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station, Wednesday, June 5, 2024, in Florida. NASA's Boeing Crew Flight Test is the first launch with astronauts of the Boeing CFT-100 spacecraft and United Launch Alliance Atlas V rocket to the International Space Station as part of the agency's Commercial Crew Program. The flight test, which launched at 10:52 a.m. EDT, serves as an end-to-end demonstration of Boeing's crew transportation system and will carry NASA astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams to and from the orbiting laboratory.\n\nCredits: NASA/Joel Kowsky\n\nNASA astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams are safely in orbit on the first crewed flight test aboard Boeing's Starliner spacecraft bound for the International Space Station.\n\nAs part of NASA's Boeing Crew Flight Test, the astronauts lifted off at 10:52 a.m. EDT Wednesday on a ULA (United Launch Alliance) Atlas V rocket from Space Launch Complex-41 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station in Florida on an end-to-end test of the Starliner system.\n\n\"Two bold NASA astronauts are well on their way on this historic first test flight of a brand-new spacecraft,\" said NASA Administrator Bill Nelson. \"Boeing's Starliner marks a new chapter of American exploration. Human spaceflight is a daring task - but that's why it's worth doing. It's an exciting time for NASA, our commercial partners, and the future of exploration. Go Starliner, Go Butch and Suni!\"\n\nAs part of NASA's Commercial Crew Program, the flight test will help validate the transportation system, launch pad, rocket, spacecraft, in-orbit operations capabilities, and return to Earth with astronauts aboard as the agency prepares to certify Starliner for rotational missions to the space station. Starliner previously flew two uncrewed orbital flights, including a test to and from the space station, along with a pad abort demonstration.\n\n\"With Starliner's launch, separation from the rocket, and arrival on orbit, Boeing's Crew Flight Test is right on track,\" said Mark Nappi, vice president and program manager of Boeing's Commercial Crew Program. \"Everyone is focused on giving Suni and Butch a safe, comfortable, ride and performing a successful test mission from start to finish.\"\n\nDuring Starliner's flight, Boeing will monitor a series of automatic spacecraft maneuvers from its mission control center in Houston. NASA teams will monitor space station operations throughout the flight from the Mission Control Center at the agency's Johnson Space Center in Houston.\n\n\"Flying crew on Starliner represents over a decade of work by the Commercial Crew Program and our partners at Boeing and ULA,\" said Steve Stich, manager, Commercial Crew Program, at NASA's Johnson Space Center in Houston. \"For many of us, this is a career-defining moment bringing on a new crew transportation capability for our agency and our nation. We are going to take it one step at a time, putting Starliner through its paces, and remaining vigilant until Butch and Suni safely touch down back on Earth at the conclusion of this test flight.\"\n\nStarliner will autonomously dock to the forward-facing port of the station's Harmony module at approximately 12:15 p.m. Thursday, June 6, and remain at the orbital laboratory for about a week.\n\nWilmore and Williams will help verify the spacecraft is performing as intended by testing the environmental control system, the displays and control system, and by maneuvering the thrusters, among other tests during flight.\n\nAfter a safe arrival at the space station, Wilmore and Williams will join the Expedition 71 crew of NASA astronauts Michael Barratt, Matt Dominick, Tracy C. Dyson, and Jeanette Epps, and Roscosmos cosmonauts Nikolai Chub, Alexander Grebenkin, and Oleg Kononenko.\n\nNASA's arrival and in-flight event coverage is as follows (all times Eastern and subject to change based on real-time operations):\n\nMission coverage will continue on NASA Television channels throughout Starliner's flight and resume on NASA+ prior to docking.\n\nThursday, June 6\n\n12:15 p.m. - Targeted docking\n\n2 p.m. - Hatch opening\n\n2:20 p.m. - Welcome remarks\n\n3:30 p.m. - Post-docking news conference at NASA Johnson with the following participants:\n\n* NASA Associate Administrator Jim Free\n\n* Steve Stich, manager, NASA's Commercial Crew Program\n\n* Jeff Arend, manager for systems engineering and integration, NASA's International Space Station Office\n\n* Mark Nappi, vice president and program manager, Commercial Crew Program, Boeing\n\n5:50 p.m. - NASA Administrator Bill Nelson, Deputy Administrator Pam Melroy, Associate Administrator Jim Free, Associate Administrator for Space Operations Ken Bowersox, and Johnson Space Center Director Vanessa Wyche will speak with Wilmore and Williams about their launch aboard the Starliner spacecraft.\n\nSaturday, June 8\n\n8:50 a.m. - NASA astronauts Wilmore and Williams will provide a tour of Starliner.\n\nMonday, June 10\n\n11 a.m. - Williams will speak to students from Sunita L. Williams Elementary School in Needham, Massachusetts, in an event aboard the space station.\n\nTuesday, June 11\n\n3:15 p.m. - Wilmore will speak to students from Tennessee Tech University in an event aboard the space station.\n\nMeet NASA's Crew\n\nWilmore is the commander for the mission. A veteran of two spaceflights, Wilmore has 178 days in space under his belt. In 2009, he served as a pilot aboard space shuttle Atlantis for the STS-129 mission. Additionally, Wilmore served as a flight engineer for Expedition 41 until November 2014, when he assumed command of the space station after arrival of the Expedition 42 crew. He returned to Earth the following March. Prior to his selection by NASA in 2000, the father of two obtained both his bachelor's degree and master's degree in Electrical Engineering from Tennessee Technological University, Cookeville, before graduating with another master's degree in Aviation Systems from the University of Tennessee, Knoxville. He is also a graduate of the United States Naval Test Pilot School, Patuxent River, Maryland, and has completed four operational deployments during his tenure as a fleet naval officer and aviator.\n\nWilliams is the spacecraft pilot for the flight test. Williams has spent 322 days in space across two missions: Expedition 14/15 in 2006 through 2007, and Expedition 32/33 in 2012. The Massachusetts native also conducted seven spacewalks, totaling 50 hours and 40 minutes. Before her career began with NASA in 1998, Williams graduated with her bachelor's degree in Physical Science from the U.S. Naval Academy, Annapolis, Maryland, before obtaining her master's degree in Engineering Management from the Florida Institute of Technology, Melbourne. In total, she has logged more than 3,000 flight hours in over 30 different aircraft.\n\nNASA's Commercial Crew Program has delivered on its goal of safe, reliable, and cost-effective transportation to and from the International Space Station from the United States through a partnership with American private industry. This partnership is changing the arc of human spaceflight history by opening access to low Earth orbit and the space station to more people, science, and commercial opportunities. The space station remains the springboard to NASA's next great leap in space exploration, including future missions to the Moon under Artemis and, eventually, Mars.\n\nLearn more about NASA's Commercial Crew program at:\n\nhttps://www.nasa.gov/commercialcrew\n\n-end-", "source": {"uri": "agenparl.eu", "dataType": "news", "title": "Agenparl"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": The lift off is scheduled at 8:22 pm IST atop the Atlas V rocket from Cape Canaveral Space Force station in Florida.\n\nAstronauts Sunita Williams and Barry Wilmore will fly to the International Space Station (ISS) on Starliner in what is Boeing's debut crew mission.\n\nThis is the third attempt to launch the astronauts after the ones on May 7 and June 1 were scrubbed due to technical anomalies.\n\nWhere to watch the launch?\n\nThe live coverage of the launch will begin at 4:15 pm on NASA's official YouTube channel, NASA TV, NASA app and the agency's website. You can also tune in to NASA's X profile and follow Boeing Space for the live updates.\n\nALSO SEE: Who Are The Crew Members Risking Their Lives For Boeing's Starliner Mission?\n\nThe Boeing crew flight test\n\nThe mission is meant to test Starliner and its ability for an end-to-end mission to the space station and back. If all goes well with the launch, NASA says that the spacecraft will dock at space station's Harmony module at 9:45 pm IST on June 6.\n\n\"Wilmore and Williams will remain at the space station for about a week to test the Starliner spacecraft and its subsystems before NASA works to complete final certification of the transportation system for rotational missions to the orbiting laboratory as part of the agency's Commercial Crew Program,\" NASA said in a statement.\n\nCurrently, SpaceX is the only company with a contract for NASA's Commercial Crew Program for ferrying astronauts and cargo to the ISS. If the CFT is successful, Boeing too will be certified for the same.\n\nALSO SEE: The Long, Thorny History Of Boeing's Starliner Spaceship\n\n(Image: NASA)", "source": {"uri": "in.mashable.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Mashable India"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_Starliner", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Boeing Starliner"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NASA", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "NASA"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Boeing"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronaut", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Astronaut"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cape_Canaveral_Space_Force_Station", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Cape Canaveral Space Force Station"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Space_Force", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "United States Space Force"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barry_E._Wilmore", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Barry E. {"uri": "8163272461", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "16:39:48", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T16:39:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T16:39:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.rte.ie/news/world/2024/0605/1453216-boeing-space/", "title": "Boeing capsule launched on first crewed space flight", "body": "Boeing's new Starliner astronaut capsule has been launched from the United States in a much-delayed first test flight carrying a crew.\n\nIt is a milestone in the aerospace company's ambitions to step up competition with SpaceX, owned by Elon Musk.\n\nThe CST-100 Starliner, with two astronauts aboard, lifted off from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station in Florida, strapped to an Atlas V rocket furnished and flown by the Boeing-Lockheed Martin joint venture United Launch Alliance (ULA).\n\nThe capsule and its crew are headed for a rendezvous with the International Space Station (ISS), two years after the Starliner completed its first test voyage to the orbital laboratory without astronauts aboard.\n\nDocking maneuvres with crew will pose another test for Starliner, followed roughly a week later by the test of returning to Earth.\n\nBoeing intends for Starliner to compete with SpaceX's Crew Dragon capsule, which since 2020 has been NASA's only vehicle for sending ISS crew members to orbit from US soil.\n\nLast-minute issues had halted the Starliner's first two crewed launch attempts.\n\nA 6 May countdown was halted two hours before liftoff over three issues that required weeks of extra scrutiny.\n\nAnother atttempt last Saturday was halted with less than four minutes to go because of a glitch with a launchpad computer.\n\nToday, the Atlas V's engines thundered to life in flaming clouds of exhaust and coolant-water vapour as the spacecraft roared off its launch pad into the sky from Florida's Atlantic coast.\n\nThe upper stage separated from the rocket's lower section about four minutes into flight, followed by Starliner's separation from the second stage.\n\nNow on its own in space, Starliner will ascend deeper and fire its onboard thrusters to plug itself into orbit and kick off its 24-hour catch-up with the ISS.\n\nThe inaugural crew for the seven-seat Starliner includes two veteran NASA astronauts: Barry \"Butch\" Wilmore, 61, a retired US Navy captain and fighter pilot, and Sunita \"Suni\" Williams, 58, a former Navy helicopter test pilot with experience flying more than 30 different aircraft.\n\nThey have spent a combined 500 days in space over the course of two ISS missions each.\n\nMr Wilmore is the designated commander for the flight, with Ms Williams in the pilot seat. They are due to spend about a week at the ISS before returning to Earth.\n\nBoeing's first time to build an operational spacecraft\n\nBoeing, with its commercial airplane operations rocked by a series of crises involving its 737 MAX planes, needs a win in space for its Starliner venture, already several years behind schedule and more than $1.5 billion (\u20ac1.38bn) over budget.\n\nTwo two years ago, it completed its first test voyage to ISS and back without astronauts aboard.\n\nThe longtime NASA contractor has built modules for the decades-old ISS and rockets designed to loft astronauts toward the moon.\n\nBut Boeing never before built its own operational spacecraft, a feat complicated by years of software issues, technical glitches and management shakeups on the Starliner programme.\n\nMeanwhile, SpaceX's Crew Dragon has become a dependable taxi to orbit for NASA.\n\nThat capsule and Starliner are among the first in a new generation of privately built spacecraft - seeded with NASA funding - designed to fly astronauts to low-Earth orbit and the moon under the US space agency's Artemis programme.\n\nIf all goes as planned, the capsule will arrive at the ISS on Thursday and dock with the orbiting research outpost 400km above Earth.\n\nAlthough Starliner is designed to fly autonomously, the crew can assume control of the spacecraft if necessary.\n\nThe test flight calls for Mr Wilmore and Ms Williams to practice manoeuvring the vehicle manually en route to the space station, where it will remain docked for at least eight days before returning to Earth.\n\nMr Wilmore and Ms Williams are due to join ISS's current seven resident crew members before riding the capsule back to Earth for a parachute and airbag-assisted landing in the US desert - a first for a crewed NASA mission.\n\nGetting Starliner to this point has been a fraught process for Boeing under its $4.2bn (\u20ac3.9bn) fixed-priced contract with NASA, which wants the redundancy of having two different US rides to the ISS, an outpost expected to retire around 2030.\n\nMeanwhile, SpaceX's fourth test launch of its Starship rocket system, another chapter in its quest to build a reusable satellite launcher and moon lander, is due for liftoff from Texas on Thursday.", "source": {"uri": "rte.ie", "dataType": "news", "title": "RTE.ie"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-379853792", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "15:45:00", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T15:45:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T15:38:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.dallasnews.com/news/2024/06/05/nasa-astronauts-off-to-space-aboard-boeing-starliner-capsule/", "title": "NASA astronauts off to space aboard Boeing Starliner capsule", "body": "NASA test pilots Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams headed to International Space Station\n\nCAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. (AP) -- Boeing launched astronauts for the first time Wednesday, belatedly joining SpaceX as a second taxi service for NASA.\n\nA pair of NASA test pilots blasted off aboard Boeing's Starliner capsule for the International Space Station, the first to fly the new spacecraft.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe trip by Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams was expected to take 25 hours, with an arrival Thursday. They will spend just over a week at the orbiting lab before climbing back into Starliner for a remote desert touchdown in the western U.S. on June 14.\n\nBreaking News\n\nGet the latest breaking news from North Texas and beyond.\n\nSIGN UP\n\nOr with:\n\nGoogle\n\nFacebook\n\nBy signing up you agree to our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy\n\n\"Let's get going!\" Wilmore called out minutes before liftoff.\n\nYears late because of spacecraft flaws, Starliner's crew debut comes as the company struggles with unrelated safety issues on its airplane side.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nWilmore and Williams -- retired Navy captains and former space station residents -- stressed repeatedly before the launch that they had full confidence in Boeing's ability to get it right with this test flight. Crippled by bad software, Starliner's initial test flight in 2019 without a crew had to be repeated before NASA would let its astronauts strap in. The 2022 do-over went much better, but parachute problems later cropped up and flammable tape had to be removed from the capsule.\n\nWednesday's launch was the third attempt with astronauts since early May, coming after a pair of rocket-related problems, most recently last weekend. A small helium leak in the spacecraft's propulsion system also caused delays, but managers decided the leak was manageable and not a safety issue.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"I know it's been a long road to get here,\" NASA's commercial crew program manager Steve Stich said before the weekend delay.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nBoeing was hired alongside Elon Musk's SpaceX a decade ago to ferry NASA's astronauts to and from the space station. The space agency wanted two competing U.S. companies for the job in the wake of the space shuttles' retirement, paying $4.2 billion to Boeing and just over half that to SpaceX, which refashioned the capsule it was using to deliver station supplies.\n\nSpaceX launched astronauts into orbit in 2020, becoming the first private business to achieve what only three countries -- Russia, the U.S. and China -- had mastered. It has taken nine crews to the space station for NASA and three private groups for a Houston company that charters flights.\n\nThe liftoff from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station was the 100th of an Atlas V for rocket maker United Launch Alliance. It was the first ride for astronauts on an Atlas rocket since John Glenn's Mercury era more than 60 years ago; the rocket usually launches satellites and other spacecraft.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nDespite the Atlas V's perfect record, the human presence cranked up the tension for the scores of NASA and Boeing employees gathered at Cape Canaveral and Mission Control in Houston.\n\nBoeing's Starliner and SpaceX's Dragon are designed to be fully autonomous and reusable. Wilmore and Williams occasionally will take manual control of Starliner on their way to the space station, to check out its systems.\n\nIf the mission goes well, NASA will alternate between SpaceX and Boeing for taxi flights, beginning next year. The backup pilot for this test flight, Mike Fincke, will strap in for Starliner's next trip.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"When you have a new spacecraft, you need to learn all about it and this has been a great exercise,\" Fincke told reporters late last week.\n\nBy MARCIA DUNN, The Associated Press\n\nThe Associated Press Health and Science Department receives support from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute's Science and Educational Media Group. {"uri": "2024-06-380017716", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "18:40:56", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T18:40:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T18:18:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://wtop.com/national/2024/06/what-to-know-about-boeings-first-spaceflight-carrying-nasa-astronauts/", "title": "What to know about Boeing's first spaceflight carrying NASA astronauts", "body": "CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. (AP) -- After years of stumbles and delays, Boeing has finally launched astronauts to the International Space...\n\nCAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. (AP) -- After years of stumbles and delays, Boeing has finally launched astronauts to the International Space Station for NASA.\n\nIt's the first flight of Boeing's Starliner capsule with a crew on board, a pair of NASA pilots who will check out the spacecraft during the test drive and a weeklong stay at the space station.\n\nNASA turned to U.S. companies for astronaut rides after the space shuttles were retired. Elon Musk's SpaceX has made nine taxi trips for NASA since 2020, while Boeing has managed only a pair of empty test flights.\n\nProvided this tryout goes well, NASA will alternate between Boeing and SpaceX to get astronauts to and from the space station.\n\nA look at the newest ride and its shakedown cruise:\n\nTHE CAPSULE\n\nWhite with black and blue trim, Boeing's Starliner capsule is about 10 feet (3 meters) tall and 15 feet (4.5 meters) in diameter. It can fit up to seven people, though NASA crews typically will number four. The company settled on the name Starliner nearly a decade ago, a twist on the name of Boeing's early Stratoliner and the current Dreamliner planes.\n\nNo one was aboard Boeing's two previous Starliner test flights. The first, in 2019, was hit with software trouble so severe that its empty capsule couldn't reach the station until the second try in 2022. Then last summer, weak parachutes and flammable tape cropped up that needed to be fixed or removed. Wednesday's launch was the third try with astronauts; two earlier countdowns were scuttled by rocket-related issues.\n\nTHE CREW\n\nVeteran NASA astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams are retired Navy captains who spent months aboard the space station years ago. They joined the test flight after the original crew bowed out as the delays piled up. Wilmore, 61, is a former combat pilot from Mount Juliet, Tennessee, and Williams, 58, is a helicopter pilot from Needham, Massachusetts.\n\nTHE TEST FLIGHT\n\nStarliner blasted off on United Launch Alliance's Atlas V rocket from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station. It's the first time astronauts have ridden an Atlas since NASA's Project Mercury, starting with John Glenn when he became the first American to orbit the Earth in 1962. Now 62 years later, Wednesday's launch was the 100th for the top-of-the-line Atlas V, which is used to hoist satellites as well as spacecraft. ULA is a joint venture of Boeing and Lockheed Martin.\n\nStarliner should reach the space station with its seven residents on Thursday. Starliner will remain docked for just over a week, undergoing checkouts before landing in the American West.\n\nSTARLINER VS. DRAGON\n\nBoth Boeing and SpaceX's capsules are designed to be autonomous and reusable. This Starliner is the same one that made the first test flight in 2019. Unlike the SpaceX Dragons, Starliner has traditional hand controls and switches alongside touchscreens and, according to the astronauts, is more like NASA's Orion capsules for moon missions. Plans called for Wilmore and Williams to briefly take manual control to test out the systems on their way to the space station.\n\nNASA gave Boeing, a longtime space contractor, more than $4 billion to develop the capsule, while SpaceX got $2.6 billion. SpaceX already was delivering supplies to the space station, and merely refashioned its cargo capsule for crew. While SpaceX uses the boss' Teslas to get astronauts to the launch pad, Boeing has a more traditional \"astrovan.\"\n\nOne big difference at flight's end: Starliner lands on the ground with cushioning airbags, while Dragon splashes into the sea.\n\nTHE FUTURE\n\nBoeing is committed to six Starliner trips for NASA after this one, which will take the company to the station's planned end in 2030. Boeing has said a fifth seat will be available to private clients. SpaceX periodically sells seats to tycoons and even countries eager to get their citizens to the station for a couple weeks, but these rides are separate from NASA's dedicated six-month missions.\n\nComing soon: Sierra Space's mini shuttle, Dream Chaser, which will attempt to deliver cargo to the station later this year, before accepting passengers. It is due to launch on ULA's new Vulcan rocket, the eventual successor to the Atlas V.\n\n___\n\nThe Associated Press Health and Science Department receives support from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute's Science and Educational Media Group. The AP is solely responsible for all content.\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "2024-06-379865734", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "15:55:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T15:55:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T15:35:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/boeing-launches-nasa-astronauts-for-the-first-time-after-years-of-delays/article_08bdb69a-8ce4-5910-bad4-74ba5a48cd0a.html", "title": "Boeing launches NASA astronauts for the first time after years of delays", "body": "CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. (AP) -- Boeing launched astronauts for the first time Wednesday, belatedly joining SpaceX as a second taxi service for NASA.\n\nA pair of NASA test pilots blasted off aboard Boeing's Starliner capsule for the International Space Station, the first to fly the new spacecraft.\n\nThe trip by Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams was expected to take 25 hours, with an arrival Thursday. They will spend just over a week at the orbiting lab before climbing back into Starliner for a remote desert touchdown in the western U.S. on June 14.\n\n\"Let's get going!\" Wilmore called out minutes before liftoff.\n\nYears late because of spacecraft flaws, Starliner's crew debut comes as the company struggles with unrelated safety issues on its airplane side.\n\nWilmore and Williams -- retired Navy captains and former space station residents -- stressed repeatedly before the launch that they had full confidence in Boeing's ability to get it right with this test flight. Crippled by bad software, Starliner's initial test flight in 2019 without a crew had to be repeated before NASA would let its astronauts strap in. The 2022 do-over went much better, but parachute problems later cropped up and flammable tape had to be removed from the capsule.\n\nWednesday's launch was the third attempt with astronauts since early May, coming after a pair of rocket-related problems, most recently last weekend. A small helium leak in the spacecraft's propulsion system also caused delays, but managers decided the leak was manageable and not a safety issue.\n\n\"I know it's been a long road to get here,\" NASA's commercial crew program manager Steve Stich said before the weekend delay.\n\nBoeing was hired alongside Elon Musk's SpaceX a decade ago to ferry NASA's astronauts to and from the space station. The space agency wanted two competing U.S. companies for the job in the wake of the space shuttles' retirement, paying $4.2 billion to Boeing and just over half that to SpaceX, which refashioned the capsule it was using to deliver station supplies.\n\nSpaceX launched astronauts into orbit in 2020, becoming the first private business to achieve what only three countries -- Russia, the U.S. and China -- had mastered. It has taken nine crews to the space station for NASA and three private groups for a Houston company that charters flights.\n\nThe liftoff from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station was the 100th of an Atlas V for rocket maker United Launch Alliance. It was the first ride for astronauts on an Atlas rocket since John Glenn's Mercury era more than 60 years ago; the rocket usually launches satellites and other spacecraft.\n\nDespite the Atlas V's perfect record, the human presence cranked up the tension for the scores of NASA and Boeing employees gathered at Cape Canaveral and Mission Control in Houston.\n\nBoeing's Starliner and SpaceX's Dragon are designed to be fully autonomous and reusable. Wilmore and Williams occasionally will take manual control of Starliner on their way to the space station, to check out its systems.\n\nIf the mission goes well, NASA will alternate between SpaceX and Boeing for taxi flights, beginning next year. The backup pilot for this test flight, Mike Fincke, will strap in for Starliner's next trip.\n\n\"When you have a new spacecraft, you need to learn all about it and this has been a great exercise,\" Fincke told reporters late last week.\n\nThe Associated Press Health and Science Department receives support from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute's Science and Educational Media Group. {"uri": "8163162310", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "15:23:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T15:23:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T15:23:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.newsbytesapp.com/news/science/boeing-s-starliner-finally-takes-to-space/story", "title": "Boeing's Starliner successfully launches NASA astronauts after years of delays", "body": "Boeing has successfully launched astronauts into space for the first time, joining SpaceX as a second taxi service for NASA. The launch took place today from Cape Canaveral, Florida, with NASA test pilots Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams, aboard Boeing's Starliner capsule. \"I know it's been a long road to get here,\" said Steve Stich, NASA's Commercial Crew Program Manager. This marks the first time the new spacecraft has been flown.\n\nThe astronauts are expected to reach the International Space Station (ISS) in 25 hours, arriving on Thursday. Wilmore and Williams will spend just over a week at the orbiting lab, before returning to Earth in the Starliner. The spacecraft is scheduled to touch down in a remote desert in the western US on June 14. Both astronauts, retired Navy captains and former space station residents, expressed confidence in Boeing ahead of the launch.\n\nThe launch of Starliner was delayed due to flaws in the spacecraft. The initial test flight in 2019 had to be repeated due to software issues, before NASA would allow its astronauts onboard. A successful do-over took place in 2022, although subsequent parachute problems led to further delays. This week's launch was the third attempt with astronauts since early May, with previous attempts thwarted by rocket-related issues, and a small helium leak in the spacecraft's propulsion system.\n\nBoeing was contracted alongside SpaceX 10 years ago, to transport NASA's astronauts to and from the ISS following the retirement of space shuttles. NASA paid $4.2 billion to Boeing for this service, slightly over half of what it paid to SpaceX. SpaceX launched astronauts into orbit in 2020, a feat previously accomplished only by Russia, the US, and China. Since then, SpaceX has taken nine crews to the ISS for NASA and three private groups for a Houston company.\n\nToday's launch marked the 100th liftoff of Atlas V for United Launch Alliance. This was the first time astronauts have ridden an Atlas rocket since John Glenn's Mercury era 60 years ago. Both Starliner and SpaceX's Dragon are designed to be autonomous and reusable. During their journey to ISS, Wilmore and Williams will occasionally take manual control of Starliner to check its systems. If this mission proves successful, NASA will alternate between SpaceX and Boeing for taxi flights starting 2025.", "source": {"uri": "newsbytesapp.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NewsBytes"}, It failed on May 29.\n\nThe astronauts will also test several aspects of the Starliner's capabilities before NASA can certify the craft for more missions.\n\nIt will be a weeklong mission, with the two astronauts expected to dock at around 12:15 p.m. on Thursday. Wilmore and Williams will then spend eight days living aboard the space station, joining seven astronauts and cosmonauts already on board.\n\nThe Starliner has attempted two launches on May 6 and Saturday and had both scrubbed, but delays on the historic launch actually trace back several years.\n\nREAD: Boeing Starliner rocket launch scrubbed right before liftoff\n\nSince Boeing was awarded $4.2 billion from NASA to transport astronauts to and from the space station, the aerospace company has been proverbially lapped by its competitor SpaceX and racked up over $1 billion in unplanned costs.\n\nIts first launch scrub on May 6 came because of a faulty oxygen relief valve, according to NASA. {"uri": "8163452386", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "19:07:37", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T19:07:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T19:06:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://gvwire.com/2024/06/05/boeing-launches-nasa-astronauts-for-the-first-time-after-years-of-delay/", "title": "Boeing Launches NASA Astronauts for the First Time After Years of Delay", "body": "CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. -- Boeing launched astronauts for the first time Wednesday, belatedly joining SpaceX as a second taxi service for NASA.\n\nA pair of NASA test pilots blasted off aboard Boeing's Starliner capsule for the International Space Station, the first to fly the new spacecraft.\n\nThe trip by Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams was expected to take 25 hours, with an arrival Thursday. They will spend just over a week at the orbiting lab before climbing back into Starliner for a remote desert touchdown in the western U.S. on June 14.\n\n\"Let's get going!\" Wilmore called out a few minutes before liftoff.\n\nHalf an hour later, he and Williams were safely in orbit and giving chase to the space station. Back at Cape Canaveral, the relieved launch controllers stood and applauded. After all the trouble leading up to Wednesday's launch, including two scrapped countdowns, everything went smoothly before and during liftoff, prompting congratulations from SpaceX's Elon Musk and others.\n\n\"Today it all lined up,\" said Boeing program manager Mark Nappi.\n\nRelated Story: June's Planetary Parade: What You Can and Can't See\n\nYears late because of spacecraft flaws, Starliner's crew debut comes as the company struggles with unrelated safety issues on its airplane side.\n\nWilmore and Williams -- retired Navy captains and former space station residents -- stressed repeatedly before the launch that they had full confidence in Boeing's ability to get it right with this test flight. Crippled by bad software, Starliner's initial test flight in 2019 without a crew had to be repeated before NASA would let its astronauts strap in. The 2022 do-over went much better, but parachute problems later cropped up and flammable tape had to be removed from the capsule.\n\nWednesday's launch was the third attempt with astronauts since early May, coming after a pair of rocket-related problems, most recently last weekend. A small helium leak in the spacecraft's propulsion system also caused delays, but remained extremely low and manageable.\n\n\"It's just a tough endeavor to get to flight and huge kudos to the entire team for getting there,\" said Steve Stich, NASA's commercial crew program manager.\n\nRelated Story: Astronomers Find the Biggest Known Batch of Planet Ingredients Swirling Around ...\n\nBoeing was hired alongside Elon Musk's SpaceX a decade ago to ferry NASA's astronauts to and from the space station. The space agency wanted two competing U.S. companies for the job in the wake of the space shuttles' retirement, paying $4.2 billion to Boeing and just over half that to SpaceX, which refashioned the capsule it was using to deliver station supplies.\n\nSpaceX launched astronauts into orbit in 2020, becoming the first private business to achieve what only three countries -- Russia, the U.S. and China -- had mastered. It has taken nine crews to the space station for NASA and three private groups for a Houston company that charters flights.\n\nThe liftoff from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station was the 100th of an Atlas V for rocket maker United Launch Alliance. It was the first ride for astronauts on an Atlas rocket since John Glenn's Mercury era more than 60 years ago; the rocket usually launches satellites and other spacecraft.\n\nDespite the Atlas V's perfect record, the human presence cranked up the tension for the scores of NASA and Boeing employees gathered at Cape Canaveral and Mission Control in Houston.\n\nRelated Story: Strong Solar Storm Could Disrupt Communications and Produce Northern Lights in ...\n\nBoeing's Starliner and SpaceX's Dragon are designed to be fully autonomous and reusable. Wilmore and Williams occasionally will take manual control of Starliner on their way to the space station, to check out its systems. The only snag early in the flight involved the capsule's cooling system. More water was used than expected before the radiators took over in orbit. The tank will be refilled before the ride home.\n\nIf the mission goes well, NASA will alternate between SpaceX and Boeing for taxi flights, beginning next year. The backup pilot for this test flight, Mike Fincke, will strap in for Starliner's next trip.\n\n\"This is exciting. We built up to this moment for years and years, and it finally happened,\" Fincke said from neighboring Kennedy Space Center. \"I feel like the whole planet was cheering for them.\"", "source": {"uri": "8163425220", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "18:43:07", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T18:43:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T18:42:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.newsday.com/business/boeing-test-flight-astronauts-space-station-u14958", "title": "What to know about Boeing's first spaceflight carrying NASA astronauts", "body": "CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. -- After years of stumbles and delays, Boeing has finally launched astronauts to the International Space Station for NASA.\n\nIt's the first flight of Boeing's Starliner capsule with a crew on board, a pair of NASA pilots who will check out the spacecraft during the test drive and a weeklong stay at the space station.\n\nNASA turned to U.S. companies for astronaut rides after the space shuttles were retired. Elon Musk's SpaceX has made nine taxi trips for NASA since 2020, while Boeing has managed only a pair of empty test flights.\n\nProvided this tryout goes well, NASA will alternate between Boeing and SpaceX to get astronauts to and from the space station.\n\nA look at the newest ride and its shakedown cruise:\n\nTHE CAPSULE\n\nWhite with black and blue trim, Boeing's Starliner capsule is about 10 feet (3 meters) tall and 15 feet (4.5 meters) in diameter. It can fit up to seven people, though NASA crews typically will number four. The company settled on the name Starliner nearly a decade ago, a twist on the name of Boeing's early Stratoliner and the current Dreamliner planes.\n\nNo one was aboard Boeing's two previous Starliner test flights. The first, in 2019, was hit with software trouble so severe that its empty capsule couldn't reach the station until the second try in 2022. Then last summer, weak parachutes and flammable tape cropped up that needed to be fixed or removed. Wednesday's launch was the third try with astronauts; two earlier countdowns were scuttled by rocket-related issues.\n\nTHE CREW\n\nVeteran NASA astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams are retired Navy captains who spent months aboard the space station years ago. They joined the test flight after the original crew bowed out as the delays piled up. Wilmore, 61, is a former combat pilot from Mount Juliet, Tennessee, and Williams, 58, is a helicopter pilot from Needham, Massachusetts.\n\nTHE TEST FLIGHT\n\nStarliner blasted off on United Launch Alliance's Atlas V rocket from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station. It's the first time astronauts have ridden an Atlas since NASA's Project Mercury, starting with John Glenn when he became the first American to orbit the Earth in 1962. Now 62 years later, Wednesday's launch was the 100th for the top-of-the-line Atlas V, which is used to hoist satellites as well as spacecraft. ULA is a joint venture of Boeing and Lockheed Martin.\n\nStarliner should reach the space station with its seven residents on Thursday. Starliner will remain docked for just over a week, undergoing checkouts before landing in the American West.\n\nSTARLINER VS. DRAGON\n\nBoth Boeing and SpaceX's capsules are designed to be autonomous and reusable. This Starliner is the same one that made the first test flight in 2019. Unlike the SpaceX Dragons, Starliner has traditional hand controls and switches alongside touchscreens and, according to the astronauts, is more like NASA's Orion capsules for moon missions. Plans called for Wilmore and Williams to briefly take manual control to test out the systems on their way to the space station.\n\nNASA gave Boeing, a longtime space contractor, more than $4 billion to develop the capsule, while SpaceX got $2.6 billion. SpaceX already was delivering supplies to the space station, and merely refashioned its cargo capsule for crew. While SpaceX uses the boss' Teslas to get astronauts to the launch pad, Boeing has a more traditional \"astrovan.\"\n\nOne big difference at flight's end: Starliner lands on the ground with cushioning airbags, while Dragon splashes into the sea.\n\nTHE FUTURE\n\nBoeing is committed to six Starliner trips for NASA after this one, which will take the company to the station's planned end in 2030. Boeing has said a fifth seat will be available to private clients. SpaceX periodically sells seats to tycoons and even countries eager to get their citizens to the station for a couple weeks, but these rides are separate from NASA's dedicated six-month missions.\n\nComing soon: Sierra Space's mini shuttle, Dream Chaser, which will attempt to deliver cargo to the station later this year, before accepting passengers. It is due to launch on ULA's new Vulcan rocket, the eventual successor to the Atlas V.", "source": {"uri": "newsday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Newsday"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri":
