"https://cassette.sphdigital.com.sg/image/businesstimes/afe4cb9d4a606c56c34d47719dd2c137a786928d2a81fa03f9cc7724218f17bb", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9622079", "eventUri": "eng-9622079", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-06-05", "textStart": 81, "textEnd": 86}], "sentiment": 0.02745098039215677, "wgt": 176, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8163195832", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "15:46:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T15:46:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T15:45:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://mcdowellnews.com/news/nation-world/science/boeing-launches-nasa-astronauts-for-the-first-time-after-years-of-delays/article_1fb141b4-8f0d-57ad-90bb-92d2804dd37a.html", "title": "Boeing launches NASA astronauts for the first time after years of delays", "body": "CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. -- Boeing launched astronauts for the first time Wednesday, belatedly joining SpaceX as a second taxi service for NASA.\n\nA pair of NASA test pilots blasted off aboard Boeing's Starliner capsule for the International Space Station, the first to fly the new spacecraft.\n\nThe trip by Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams was expected to take 25 hours, with an arrival Thursday. They will spend just over a week at the orbiting lab before climbing back into Starliner for a remote desert touchdown in the western U.S. on June 14.\n\nYears late because of spacecraft flaws, Starliner's crew debut comes as the company struggles with unrelated safety issues on its airplane side.\n\nPeople are also reading... Marion man charged in death by distribution case Nebo Crossing Academy celebrates 15 graduates Missing Davie County woman and her husband found dead Friday. Ashanti Alert was issued Thursday for Cynthia Gobble Marion police: 649 grams of marijuana, 1.8 grams of cocaine found during traffic stop McDowell County juvenile arrested last week for assault of school administrators Traffic stop leads to narcotics arrest by Marion police In wake of shootout, Hickory pub featured on 'Bar Rescue' TV show loses liquor license Two arrested in Marion after traffic stop turns up narcotics Nebo couple arrested, charged following home raid Greensboro Baptist pastor arrested by FBI, says he will be 'vindicated by God' Old Fort's Catawba Falls Trail set to reopen Friday after 2 years closed 'PAPER TRAIL TO THE PATRIOT' Woman of color, descendant of John Carson joins McDowell DAR McDowell County Schools Alumni Spotlight: Sheriff Ricky Buchanan Reporter, wife, dog have lunch at Switzerland Caf\u00e9\n\nWilmore and Williams -- retired Navy captains and former space station residents -- stressed repeatedly before the launch that they had full confidence in Boeing's ability to get it right with this test flight. Crippled by bad software, Starliner's initial test flight in 2019 without a crew had to be repeated before NASA would let its astronauts strap in. The 2022 do-over went much better, but parachute problems later cropped up and flammable tape had to be removed from the capsule.\n\nWednesday's launch was the third attempt with astronauts since early May, coming after a pair of rocket-related problems, most recently last weekend. A small helium leak in the spacecraft's propulsion system also caused delays, but managers decided the leak was manageable and not a safety issue.\n\n\"I know it's been a long road to get here,\" NASA's commercial crew program manager Steve Stich said before the weekend delay.\n\nBoeing was hired alongside Elon Musk's SpaceX a decade ago to ferry NASA's astronauts to and from the space station. The space agency wanted two competing U.S. companies for the job in the wake of the space shuttles' retirement, paying $4.2 billion to Boeing and just over half that to SpaceX, which refashioned the capsule it was using to deliver station supplies.\n\nSpaceX launched astronauts into orbit in 2020, becoming the first private business to achieve what only three countries -- Russia, the U.S. and China -- had mastered. It has taken nine crews to the space station for NASA and three private groups for a Houston company that charters flights.\n\nThe liftoff from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station was the 100th of an Atlas V for rocket maker United Launch Alliance. It was the first ride for astronauts on an Atlas rocket since John Glenn's Mercury era more than 60 years ago; the rocket usually launches satellites and other spacecraft.\n\nDespite the Atlas V's perfect record, the human presence cranked up the tension for the scores of NASA and Boeing employees gathered at Cape Canaveral and Mission Control in Houston.\n\nBoeing's Starliner and SpaceX's Dragon are designed to be fully autonomous and reusable. Wilmore and Williams occasionally will take manual control of Starliner on their way to the space station, to check out its systems.\n\nIf the mission goes well, NASA will alternate between SpaceX and Boeing for taxi flights, beginning next year. The backup pilot for this test flight, Mike Fincke, will strap in for Starliner's next trip.\n\n\"When you have a new spacecraft, you need to learn all about it and this has been a great exercise,\" Fincke told reporters late last week.\n\nThe Associated Press Health and Science Department receives support from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute's Science and Educational Media Group. The AP is solely responsible for all content.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8163247077", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "16:22:02", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T16:22:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T16:21:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/liftoff-finally-boeing-starliner-launches-first-crew-on-third-try/article_af45aa25-fb6f-535c-adbd-1ae343d8ca3c.html", "title": "Liftoff, finally: Boeing Starliner launches first crew on third try", "body": "The Boeing Starliner capsule blasted off atop a United Launch Alliance Atlas V rocket at 10:52 am (1452 GMT) from the Cape Canaveral Space Force Station in Florida\n\nBoeing on Wednesday launched its very first astronauts bound for the International Space Station aboard a Starliner capsule, which joins a select club of spacecraft to carry humans beyond Earth.\n\nThe third time turned out to be the charm for the aerospace giant, after two previous bids to fly with crew were aborted late into the countdown, for technical reasons.\n\nAstronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams, both of whom have two previous spaceflights under their belts, blasted off at 10:52 am (1452 GMT) from the Cape Canaveral Space Force Station in Florida, for a roughly one-week stay at the station.\n\n\"Suni and I are honored to share this dream of spaceflight with each and every one of you,\" Wilmore, who is commander of the test flight, said just before liftoff. \"Let's put some fire in this rocket, and let's push it to the heavens.\"\n\nStarliner becomes just the sixth type of US-built spaceship to fly NASA astronauts, following the Mercury, Gemini and Apollo programs in the 1960s and 1970s, the Space Shuttle from 1981 to 2011, and SpaceX's Crew Dragon from 2020.\n\nThe Starliner program has been beset by years of safety scares and delays, and a successful mission will offer Boeing a much-needed reprieve from the intense safety concerns surrounding its passenger jets.\n\nNASA meanwhile is looking to certify Boeing as a second commercial operator to ferry crews to the ISS -- something Elon Musk's SpaceX has already been doing for the US space agency for four years.\n\n- Embarrassing setbacks -\n\nBoth companies received multibillion-dollar contracts in 2014 to develop their crew capsules, following the end of the Space Shuttle program that left the US temporarily reliant on Russian rockets for rides.\n\nBoeing, with its 100-year history, was heavily favored, but its program fell badly behind.\n\nSetbacks ranged from a software bug that put the spaceship on a bad trajectory on its first uncrewed test, to the discovery that the cabin was filled with flammable electrical tape after the second.\n\nMore from this section Newburgh business owners: Cashless parking meters are driving away customers Policing Minister: Voters can take our promise of a reduction in migration 'to the bank' LS Polls 2024 Results: Shashi Tharoor Celebrates Big Win In Thiruvananthapuram, Distribute Sweets\n\nThe first crewed launch attempt on May 6 was scuppered in the final hours due to a buzzy valve on the United Launch Alliance Atlas V rocket the capsule sits atop.\n\nThen on Saturday, things were even more dramatic with liftoff aborted with less than four minutes left on the countdown clock as the ground launch computer went into an automatic hold.\n\nThe problem was later traced to a faulty power supply source connected to the computer, with the malfunctioning unit since replaced.\n\nIn both cases, Wilmore and Williams were strapped in and ready to go, only to be forced to return to strict quarantine in their quarters.\n\nThe pair of ex-Navy test pilots might have been forgiven for thinking they were stuck in Groundhog Day as they waved their goodbyes to their families on Wednesday morning and headed to the astrovan that led them to the launchpad.\n\nWhile teams worked to replace the faulty rocket valve that postponed the first crewed launch attempt, a small helium leak located in one of Starliner's thrusters came to light.\n\nRather than replace the seal, which would require taking the spaceship apart in its factory, NASA and Boeing officials declared it safe enough to fly as is.\n\nThe astronauts will now be charged with putting Starliner through the wringer, including taking manual control of the spacecraft on its way to the ISS.\n\nDuring their stay on the research platform, they will continue to evaluate the craft, including simulating whether the ship can be used as a safe haven in the event of problems on the orbital outpost.\n\nAfter undocking, Starliner will re-enter the atmosphere, with the crew experiencing 3.5G as they slow down from 17,500 miles an hour (28,000 kph) to a gentle parachute and airbag-assisted landing in the western United States.\n\nia/des", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro Reformer"}, "authors": [{"uri": "gianrigo_marletta@reformer.com", "name": "Gianrigo Marletta", "type": {"uri": "8163278789", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "16:44:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T16:44:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T16:43:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.capitalgazette.com/2024/06/05/watch-live-boeings-starliner-set-for-launch-this-morning-on-historic-1st-human-spaceflight/", "title": "Boeing's Starliner launches on historic 1st human spaceflight for NASA", "body": "KENNEDY SPACE CENTER -- A pair of NASA astronauts have finally taken their historic ride on Boeing's CST-100 Starliner making its first-ever human spaceflight Wednesday morning.\n\nBarry \"Butch\" Wilmore and Sunita \"Suni\" Williams were back for a third time in a month once again taking a ride out to Cape Canaveral Space Force Station's Space Launch Complex 41 to climb on board the spacecraft sitting atop a United Launch Alliance Atlas V rocket that lifted off amid mostly clear skies at 10:52 a.m. to take the pair to the International Space Station.\n\n\"Let's get going,\" said Wilmore minutes before launch. \"Let's put some fire in this rocket and let's push it to the heavens where all these tough Americans have prepared it to be.\"\n\nThe pair are flying the Crew Flight Test mission, a followup to two uncrewed test flights of Starliner, the first of which came in 2019. That mission was a partial failure as it was not able to rendezvous with the ISS forcing a 2 1/2-year delay to Boeing's program to remedy hardware, software and management issues. The second uncrewed test flight in 2022 made it to the ISS, but post-launch review and preparation for the CFT brought further delays with more hardware issues popping up.\n\nBut half a decade later, Williams and Wilmore were set to fly, entering quarantine on April 22. Finally, on May 6, they tried for the first time to take off from the Space Coast, but an issue with a fluttering valve on ULA's upper Centaur stage scrubbed that attempt with about two hours to go on the countdown clock. Then a second attempt this past Saturday was scrubbed within four minutes of launch because of ULA computers not synching at the launch pad.\n\n\"I am very impressed with my colleagues for being such optimists and such professionals.\" said NASA astronaut for future Starliner crew member Mike Fincke during NASA's live commentary leading up to launch. \"They've been in quarantine for a long time. You know we've been waiting for over five years to get Starliner launched, but they are very, very excited about today. You can see that they're focused on getting the job done and they are very ready for this mission.\"\n\nIn the end, the third attempt went smoothly.\n\n\"Everything was fine. No hiccups, no drama and nothing to worry about,\" Fincke said. \"So I was really happy for Butch and Suni and happy with the whole team. ... Now we just got to get to space station.\"\n\nThe duo began suiting up before 6 a.m. at KSC's Neil Armstrong Operations & Checkout Building venturing out after 7:30 a.m. to climb aboard the updated Starliner-themed Airstream Astrovan for the ride over to neighboring Cape Canaveral and make their way back on board the Starliner spacecraft.\n\nBefore driving over, they played a traditional prelaunch game with chief of the astronaut office, Joe Acaba, not leaving until they had lost to Acaba -- this time in a quick game of Rock, Paper, Scissors. The idea is that losing that game is the worst thing that happens on a launch day.\n\n\"Speaking as a child of the 70s, a lot of us watched \"Mr. Rogers Neighborhood\" and Mr. Rogers would tell us to take our time to do it right, and that's what we're doing here,\" Fincke said.\n\nJust before 9 a.m., teams waited the conclusion of a weather brief before moving forward with hatch closure, but were given the go for hatch closure with less than two hours to go before launch.\n\n\"We are ready. We're smiling out here, see you in a couple weeks,\" said Wilmore.\n\nPictures: Launch day for Boeing's CST-100 Starliner on Crew Flight Test\n\nThe astronauts will spend just over 25 hours making their way to the ISS set to dock Thursday at 12:15 p.m., where they will spend about eight days on board before returning to Earth for a landing in one of five locations in the desert in the southwestern United States.\n\nIf successful, this will be the final required mission for Boeing under NASA's Commercial Crew Program to achieve certification and set up regular rotational missions to the ISS, sharing duties with SpaceX.\n\n\"We need that access,\" said NASA Associate Administrator Jim Free. \"So right now we have we have one provider giving us that access to the space station. This will give us a second provider, which means if we have a problem with either, we have ways to get our crews to and from station, which helps keep the tempo that we've had for 23 years of having humans in low-Earth orbit, but also that opportunity to get the crews back if there's an issue at all and keep that presence going.\"\n\nWilmore and Williams will spend time on both the way up and down from the ISS testing out manual control overrides among other facets of the mostly automated spacecraft.\n\n\"There's a thought of how things should be, but then there's the reality how things need to be,\" said Wilmore ahead of the launch attempt. \"That's what this test is all -- everything we do is test. It's been a process over the years that is such a benefit in all aspects of the capabilities of this spacecraft, and we're excited to be a part of it.\"\n\nThe pair are former Navy test pilots and veterans of two spaceflight each, with both having traveled on board Russia Soyuz capsules as well as the space shuttle. Wilmore is commander and joined NASA's astronaut corps in 2000 while Williams joined in 1998.\n\nWilliams was given the honor to name the capsule after it landed, and dubbed it Calypso, in deference to oceanographer Jacques Cousteau'sfamed vessel. The zero-gravity indicator for the mission follows the maritime theme, a stuffed narwhal that is also named Calypso.\n\nThe flight comes just over four years since SpaceX made its first crewed flight to the ISS with its Crew Dragon spacecraft, which has since flown 13 times carrying 50 humans to space. That includes the four members of Crew-8 awaiting along with the rest of the seven-person crew of Expedition 71 aboard the ISS.\n\nStarliner is only the sixth ever U.S.-based spacecraft to fly with NASA astronauts following Mercury, Gemini, Apollo, the space shuttleand SpaceX's Crew Dragon. Williams is the first woman to fly on an orbital test flight among NASA's spacecraft.\n\nStarliner will also become the first U.S.-based capsule to make a land touchdown as Crew Dragon, Apollo, Gemini and Mercury all made waterlandings, as will the Artemis program's Orion capsule that has yet to fly with humans. Russia's Soyuz, though, features land touchdowns.\n\nIt also marked a return of human launches from Cape Canaveral's launch pads, which last saw a crewed flight in 1968 with the launch of Apollo7. Every Apollo mission afterward as well as the space shuttle and Crew Dragon launches have come from nearby Kennedy Space Center.\n\nIt's the first time an Atlas V has flown with humans as well, although earlier iterations of the Atlas rocket flew several human spaceflights in the early 1960s including John Glenn's historic trip to space as the first American to each orbit in 1962.\n\nThis also marked the 100th launch of an Atlas V rocket, and Wilmore had a special message for ULA after launch.\n\n\"They've been a member of the family for a long time, but now it's official, and we want to welcome them to human spaceflight,\" he said.", "source": {"uri": "capitalgazette.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Capital Gazette"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-06-379966551", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "17:40:40", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T17:40:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T17:39:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.quiverquant.com/news/Boeing%20Starliner%E2%80%99s%20First%20Crewed%20Mission%20Takes%20Flight%20Amid%20Delays", "title": "Boeing Starliner's First Crewed Mission Takes Flight Amid Delays", "body": "Boeing's (BA) Starliner spacecraft successfully launched its first astronaut mission after multiple setbacks and delays. The spacecraft, carrying astronauts Barry Wilmore and Sunita Williams, lifted off from Cape Canaveral, Florida, at 10:52 a.m. ET on Wednesday. This mission, crucial for Boeing and NASA, faced numerous technical issues that postponed its original schedule. The launch proceeded smoothly, with Starliner completing an orbital-insertion burn about 30 minutes into the flight, setting it on course to reach the International Space Station (ISS) on Thursday.\n\nThis mission serves as a final test before Starliner can be certified to regularly transport NASA crews to and from the ISS. Initial plans for the mission were delayed due to problems with the United Launch Alliance-built Atlas V booster rocket and the Starliner itself, including a helium leak and a glitch in a ground system. These issues were resolved, allowing the launch to proceed. NASA has emphasized the importance of identifying and rectifying such technical problems on the ground to ensure mission safety.\n\nBoeing has been working on the Starliner project since 2014, alongside SpaceX, which has already successfully completed multiple missions for NASA. Boeing's journey with Starliner has been fraught with challenges, including software coding problems and valve issues, leading to $1.4 billion in accounting losses. Successful completion of this mission would bring Boeing closer to fulfilling its contract with NASA, allowing it to conduct six more crewed missions to the ISS.\n\nBoeing's efforts to overcome the technical hurdles and ensure the spacecraft's readiness highlight the complexities of space missions. The successful launch marks a significant milestone for the company, reaffirming its role in US space exploration. The upcoming docking with the ISS and the astronauts' stay will be closely monitored, with the aim of securing NASA's certification for future missions. This milestone also underscores the competitive landscape between Boeing and SpaceX in the realm of commercial spaceflight.", "source": {"uri": "quiverquant.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "quiverquant.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing_Starliner", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Boeing Starliner"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spacecraft", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Spacecraft"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NASA", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "NASA"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boeing", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Boeing"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Space_Station", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "International Space Station"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronaut", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Astronaut"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barry_E._Wilmore", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Barry E. {"uri": "8163542640", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "20:31:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T20:31:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T20:30:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.sentinelsource.com/news/national_world/boeing-s-starliner-launches-on-historic-1st-human-spaceflight-for-nasa/article_1252f981-9203-5713-9436-6acdd7150f36.html", "title": "Boeing's Starliner launches on historic 1st human spaceflight for NASA", "body": "KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla. -- A pair of NASA astronauts have finally taken their historic ride on Boeing's CST-100 Starliner making its first-ever human spaceflight Wednesday morning.\n\nBarry \"Butch\" Wilmore and Sunita \"Suni\" Williams were back for a third time in a month once again taking a ride out to Cape Canaveral Space Force Station's Space Launch Complex 41 to climb on board the spacecraft sitting atop a United Launch Alliance Atlas V rocket that lifted off amid mostly clear skies at 10:52 a.m. to take the pair to the International Space Station.\n\n\"Let's get going,\" said Wilmore minutes before launch. \"Let's put some fire in this rocket and let's push it to the heavens where all these tough Americans have prepared it to be.\"\n\nThe pair are flying the Crew Flight Test mission, a follow-up to two uncrewed test flights of Starliner, the first of which came in 2019. That mission was a partial failure as it was not able to rendezvous with the ISS forcing a 2\u00bd-year delay to Boeing's program to remedy hardware, software and management issues. The second uncrewed test flight in 2022 made it to the ISS, but post-launch review and preparation for the CFT brought further delays with more hardware issues popping up.\n\nBut half a decade later, Williams and Wilmore were set to fly, entering quarantine on April 22. Finally, on May 6, they tried for the first time to take off from the Space Coast, but an issue with a fluttering valve on ULA's upper Centaur stage scrubbed that attempt with about two hours to go on the countdown clock. Then a second attempt this past Saturday was scrubbed within four minutes of launch because of ULA computers not synching at the launch pad.\n\n\"I am very impressed with my colleagues for being such optimists and such professionals.\" said NASA astronaut for future Starliner crew member Mike Fincke during NASA's live commentary leading up to launch. \"They've been in quarantine for a long time. You know we've been waiting for over five years to get Starliner launched, but they are very, very excited about today. You can see that they're focused on getting the job done and they are very ready for this mission.\"\n\nIn the end, the third attempt went smoothly.\n\n\"Everything was fine. No hiccups, no drama and nothing to worry about,\" Fincke said. \"So I was really happy for Butch and Suni and happy with the whole team. ... Now we just got to get to space station.\"\n\nThe duo began suiting up before 6 a.m. at KSC's Neil Armstrong Operations & Checkout Building venturing out after 7:30 a.m. to climb aboard the updated Starliner-themed Airstream Astrovan for the ride over to neighboring Cape Canaveral and make their way back on board the Starliner spacecraft.\n\nBefore driving over, they played a traditional prelaunch game with chief of the astronaut office, Joe Acaba, not leaving until they had lost to Acaba -- this time in a quick game of Rock, Paper, Scissors. The idea is that losing that game is the worst thing that happens on a launch day.\n\n\"Speaking as a child of the '70s, a lot of us watched \"Mr. Rogers Neighborhood\" and Mr. Rogers would tell us to take our time to do it right, and that's what we're doing here,\" Fincke said.\n\nJust before 9 a.m., teams waited the conclusion of a weather brief before moving forward with hatch closure, but were given the go for hatch closure with less than two hours to go before launch.\n\n\"We are ready. We're smiling out here, see you in a couple weeks,\" said Wilmore.\n\nThe astronauts will spend just over 25 hours making their way to the ISS set to dock Thursday at 12:15 p.m., where they will spend about eight days on board before returning to Earth for a landing in one of five locations in the desert in the southwestern United States.\n\nIf successful, this will be the final required mission for Boeing under NASA's Commercial Crew Program to achieve certification and set up regular rotational missions to the ISS, sharing duties with SpaceX.\n\n\"We need that access,\" said NASA Associate Administrator Jim Free. \"So right now we have we have one provider giving us that access to the space station. This will give us a second provider, which means if we have a problem with either, we have ways to get our crews to and from station, which helps keep the tempo that we've had for 23 years of having humans in low-Earth orbit, but also that opportunity to get the crews back if there's an issue at all and keep that presence going.\"\n\nWilmore and Williams will spend time on both the way up and down from the ISS testing out manual control overrides among other facets of the mostly automated spacecraft.\n\n\"There's a thought of how things should be, but then there's the reality how things need to be,\" said Wilmore ahead of the launch attempt. \"That's what this test is all -- everything we do is test. It's been a process over the years that is such a benefit in all aspects of the capabilities of this spacecraft, and we're excited to be a part of it.\"\n\nThe pair are former Navy test pilots and veterans of two spaceflight each, with both having traveled on board Russia Soyuz capsules as well as the space shuttle. Wilmore is commander and joined NASA's astronaut corps in 2000 while Williams joined in 1998.\n\nWilliams was given the honor to name the capsule after it landed, and dubbed it Calypso, in deference to oceanographer Jacques Cousteau's famed vessel. The zero-gravity indicator for the mission follows the maritime theme, a stuffed narwhal that is also named Calypso.\n\nThe flight comes just over four years since SpaceX made its first crewed flight to the ISS with its Crew Dragon spacecraft, which has since flown 13 times carrying 50 humans to space. That includes the four members of Crew-8 awaiting along with the rest of the seven-person crew of Expedition 71 aboard the ISS.\n\nStarliner is only the sixth ever U.S.-based spacecraft to fly with NASA astronauts following Mercury, Gemini, Apollo, the space shuttleand SpaceX's Crew Dragon. Williams is the first woman to fly on an orbital test flight among NASA's spacecraft.\n\nStarliner will also become the first U.S.-based capsule to make a land touchdown as Crew Dragon, Apollo, Gemini and Mercury all made waterlandings, as will the Artemis program's Orion capsule that has yet to fly with humans. Russia's Soyuz, though, features land touchdowns.\n\nIt also marked a return of human launches from Cape Canaveral's launch pads, which last saw a crewed flight in 1968 with the launch of Apollo7. Every Apollo mission afterward as well as the space shuttle and Crew Dragon launches have come from nearby Kennedy Space Center.\n\nIt's the first time an Atlas V has flown with humans as well, although earlier iterations of the Atlas rocket flew several human spaceflights in the early 1960s including John Glenn's historic trip to space as the first American to each orbit in 1962.\n\nThis also marked the 100th launch of an Atlas V rocket, and Wilmore had a special message for ULA after launch.\n\n\"They've been a member of the family for a long time, but now it's official, and we want to welcome them to human spaceflight,\" he said.", "source": {"uri": "sentinelsource.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "SentinelSource.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": They had been training and quarantining in Houston while awaiting the opportunity to return to space.\n\nAmong Wilmore's accomplishments, he served as a pilot aboard Space Shuttle Atlantis in 2009. The Tennessee native is also married and has two daughters, according to his NASA biography.\n\nWilliams, 58, joined NASA in 1998 and ranks second on the list of total cumulative spacewalk time by a female astronaut, with 50 hours and 40 minutes, per NASA.\n\nRelated: NASA Seeks Volunteers for Second Mars Simulation Mission -- but There Are a Few Constraints\n\nThe launch was delayed two previous times: On Monday, May 6, the astronauts were strapped into the spacecraft and hours away from launch when the test flight was canceled because of an issue with the Atlas V rocket, which helps propel the vehicle, according to NBC News.\n\nWhile working to address the problem, a helium leak in the Starliner capsule's propulsion system was discovered, NASA reported.\n\nOn Saturday, June 1, the spacecraft was less than four minutes away from liftoff when the ground launch sequencer -- the computer that launches the rocket -- triggered an automatic hold.\n\nNever miss a story -- sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer, from celebrity news to compelling human interest stories.\n\nThe good news for Boeing comes amid a string of serious incidents involving its airplanes that have called the company's safety measures into question, including in January, when Alaska Airlines Flight 1282 had a plug door -- part of its fuselage -- blow out mid-air on its way from Oregon to California.\n\nThe Starliner will travel just over 24 hours before meeting up with cosmonauts Oleg Kononenko, Nikolai Chub and Alexander Grebenkin, along with NASA's Matthew Dominick, Michael Barratt, Jeanette Epps and Tracy Dyson at the space station.\n\nThe Starliner is scheduled to return to Earth and land at New Mexico's White Sands Missile Range The capsule, carrying veteran NASA astronauts Sunita \"Suni\" Williams and Barry \"Butch\" Wilmore, is expected to reach a stable orbit about 30 minutes after liftoff. The craft will then perform a series of maneuvers to put it on course to link up with the space station on Thursday for a roughly week-long stay.\n\nWednesday's test is the culmination of years of delays caused by technical glitches and failures with the Starliner craft. Those include an earlier botched 2019 test flight and fresh concerns over the past month of a still-unresolved helium leak NASA is monitoring throughout the mission.\n\nNASA is using the flight to prove Starliner can safely carry people to and from the ISS under the US space agency's Commercial Crew Program.\n\nIn 2014, NASA awarded Boeing $4.2 billion and Elon Musk's SpaceX $2.6 billion to create vehicles to ferry the agency's astronauts to space. {"uri": "8163151298", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "15:17:04", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T15:17:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T15:16:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.engadget.com/boeings-first-crewed-starliner-mission-is-finally-heading-to-the-iss-151053557.html", "title": "Boeing's first crewed Starliner mission is finally heading to the ISS", "body": "The spacecraft successfully blasted off after a series of delays.\n\nBoeing's first Starliner flight with a human crew onboard has successfully blasted off to space on top of United Launch Alliance's Atlas V rocket, almost a month after it was originally scheduled to launch. NASA astronauts Butch Wilmore and Sunita Williams entered the Starliner capsule and completed necessary checks by 10:08AM ET. Less than 30 minutes after the astronauts entered the capsule, the CEO ULA tweeted that the company was \"working an issue with topping valves on the ground side\" and that it was running the fix through its Software Integration Lab (SIL) before it's executed. In the end, ULA was able to implement a workaround, and the spacecraft lifted off at 10:52am ET.\n\nBack on May 6, the companies scrubbed the flight two hours after it was originally scheduled to launch after their ground teams detected \"anomalous behavior by the pressure regulation valve in the liquid oxygen tank of the Centaur upper stage of the ULA Atlas V launch vehicle.\" The valve was replaced and the Starliner teams were ready to make another launch attempt when they encountered another issue: They found a \"small helium leak\" in the spacecraft's service module.\n\nNASA and Boeing had to push back Starliner's launch date in order to investigate the leak and figure out how it would affect the flight. They eventually determined that it didn't pose a threat to the mission's safety, so they scheduled a launch attempt for June 1. Last week's launch was also scrubbed last minute due to the \"computer ground launch sequencer not loading into the correct operational configuration after proceeding into terminal count.\"\n\nAside from the NASA astronauts, Starliner flew with 760 pounds of cargo, including 300 pounds of food and other supplies requested by the crew that's currently onboard the International Space Station. Wilmore and Williams will spend eight days on the ISS conducting tests to help determine whether the Starliner is ready for regular flights to the orbiting laboratory. NASA said that if the mission is completed successfully, it will begin the final process of \"certifying Starliner and its systems for crewed rotation missions to the space station.\"", "source": A United Launch Alliance Atlas V rocket, carrying Boeing's Starliner spacecraft and NASA astronauts Butch Wilmore, commander, and Suni Williams, pilot, are on a course to the International Space Station (ISS).\n\nThe crew is on a roughly 25.5-hour journey with rendezvous and docking expected at 12:15 p.m. EDT, Thursday, June 6.\n\nThe crew flight test mission makes history in several ways. As the first crewed launch of Boeing's Starliner spacecraft, Williams is the first female astronaut to fly on the first flight of a crewed spacecraft. {"uri": "2024-06-380073957", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "20:00:02", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T20:00:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T19:38:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.1news.co.nz/2024/06/06/boeing-launches-nasa-astronauts-for-first-time-after-years-of-delays/", "title": "Boeing launches NASA astronauts for first time after years of delays", "body": "Boeing launched astronauts for the first time overnight, belatedly joining SpaceX as a second taxi service for NASA.\n\nA pair of NASA test pilots blasted off aboard Boeing's Starliner capsule for the International Space Station, the first to fly the new spacecraft.\n\nThe trip by Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams was expected to take 25 hours. They will spend just over a week at the orbiting lab before climbing back into Starliner for a remote desert touchdown in the western US on June 14.\n\n\"Let's get going!\" Wilmore called out a few minutes before liftoff.\n\nHalf an hour later, he and Williams were safely in orbit and giving chase to the space station. Back at Cape Canaveral, the relieved launch controllers stood and applauded.\n\nAfter all the trouble leading up to this week's launch, including two scrapped countdowns, everything went smoothly before and during liftoff, prompting congratulations from SpaceX's Elon Musk and others.\n\n\"Today it all lined up,\" said Boeing programme manager Mark Nappi.\n\nYears late because of spacecraft flaws, Starliner's crew debut comes as the company struggles with unrelated safety issues on its airplane side.\n\nWilmore and Williams -- retired Navy captains and former space station residents -- stressed repeatedly before the launch that they had full confidence in Boeing's ability to get it right with this test flight. Crippled by bad software, Starliner's initial test flight in 2019 without a crew had to be repeated before NASA would let its astronauts strap in.\n\nThe 2022 do-over went much better, but parachute problems later cropped up and flammable tape had to be removed from the capsule.\n\nThe launch was the third attempt with astronauts since early May, coming after a pair of rocket-related problems, most recently last weekend.\n\nA small helium leak in the spacecraft's propulsion system also caused delays, but remained extremely low and manageable.\n\n\"It's just a tough endeavour to get to flight and huge kudos to the entire team for getting there,\" said Steve Stich, NASA's commercial crew programme manager.\n\nBoeing was hired alongside Elon Musk's SpaceX a decade ago to ferry NASA's astronauts to and from the space station.", "source": {"uri": "1news.co.nz", "dataType": "news", "title": "1 News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@1news.co.nz", "name": "Associated Press", {"uri": "8163468249", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "19:21:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T19:21:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T19:20:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://www.chiangraitimes.com/news/launch-of-boeings-starliner-capsule/", "title": "Launch Of Boeing's Starliner Capsule And Crew After Long Delays - CTN News", "body": "Boeing's Starliner spacecraft, carrying two astronauts from NASA, entered orbit approximately twelve minutes after taking off from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station.\n\nIn order to catch up with the International Space Station, the crew will spend the next quarter of an hour racing against the clock.\n\nBarry \"Butch\" Wilmore, an astronaut, will serve as the mission's commander, and Sunita \"Suni\" Williams will conduct the trip as the mission pilot. This mission will mark the first time that the commercially made capsule will carry humans. It is anticipated that the capsule will arrive at the station at about 12:15 p.m. Eastern Time on Thursday night.\n\nThere were fewer than four minutes left on Saturday when the countdown was halted. A malfunction in the flight computers that are responsible for controlling launch was the root cause.\n\nIn preparation for the mission scheduled for Wednesday, the launch corporation, United Launch Alliance (ULA), changed a power supply on the system. This comes after an effort to launch the Atlas V rocket was unsuccessful a month ago due to a valve that was malfunctioning on the Centaur, which is the upper stage of the rocket.\n\nWith the Space Shuttle's retirement in 2011, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) established a cooperation with two commercial companies, Boeing and SpaceX, to transport people to and from the International Space Station.\n\nNevertheless, Boeing has fallen behind SpaceX, which has now successfully completed nine missions for NASA and four flights for private companies.\n\nNASA and Boeing were under the impression that a re-launch in 2022 would be successful; however, it was later discovered that there were issues with the capsule's parachute systems.\n\nAdditionally, the tape that was utilized to manage the hundreds of feet of cable that was contained within the spaceship was found to be combustible during the examination. These issues were resolved by Boeing, and the company was able to obtain NASA's authorization to launch the crew.\n\nThe initial attempt to launch this crewed mission that had been scheduled for the previous month was canceled due to a difficulty that had arisen with the rocket that was responsible for sending Starliner into space.\n\nIn the event that Starliner docks with the space station, Willmore and Williams will conduct tests on the essential systems of the spacecraft, which will include communication and life support. In spite of the fact that the spacecraft is capable of effectively flying itself, the two will experiment with human controls when it gets closer to the orbiting base.\n\nIt is anticipated that the crew will remain on the station for approximately one week before landing in the southwest region of the United States using parachutes as a cover. A review of the flight data will be conducted by teams from NASA and Boeing prior to the vehicle being certified for operational flying missions.\n\nThe National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) plans to divide astronaut flights between Boeing and SpaceX, with SpaceX going to the International Space Station approximately once every six months.\n\nSEE ALSO:", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8160013566", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-03", "time": "21:12:04", "dateTime": "2024-06-03T21:12:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-03T21:09:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://wonderfulengineering.com/boeings-1st-starliner-astronaut-launch-delayed-for-the-sixth-time-in-a-month/", "title": "Boeing's 1st Starliner Astronaut Launch Delayed For The Sixth Time In A Month", "body": "Boeing's highly anticipated first crewed launch of its Starliner spacecraft was abruptly halted mere minutes before liftoff on June 1, pushing the mission back to no earlier than June 5. The automatic abort was triggered by the ground launch sequencer (GLS) computer just 3 minutes and 50 seconds before the scheduled launch, leaving the exact cause unclear. The incident occurred when Boeing's Starliner together with its Atlas V rocket was to ferry NASA astronauts Butch Wilmore and Sunita Williams from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station in Florida to the International Space Station (ISS) at 12:25 p.m. EDT (1625 GMT). Despite disappointment, Steve Stich, NASA's Commercial Crew Program manager, held onto his resolve and underscored safety as a top priority for the situation along with the need for a comprehensive investigation.\n\nThere was a decision made by NASA, Boeing, and United Launch Alliance (ULA). They abandoned the possibility of using a window on June 2nd to conduct a detailed examination of the issue. The delay was detailed in a NASA update where it pointed out that the issue is about a likely bad computer card that controls ground systems at Space Launch Complex-41. Tory Bruno, who is the CEO of ULA, had this to say concerning troubleshooting: it would necessitate the removal of fuel from the rocket before engineers can take it apart and ensure an appropriate safe distance for personnel.\n\nWhile the team aims to resolve the issue swiftly, backup launch dates on June 5 and June 6 have been identified. If more time is needed, a 10-day stand-down might be necessary for vehicle battery replacements.\n\nA successful launch on June 5 would occur at 10:52 a.m. EDT (1452 GMT), with a NASA webcast starting four hours earlier. The Starliner mission, under a $4.2 billion contract with NASA's Commercial Crew Program, has faced multiple delays over recent years, including a scrubbed launch on May 6 due to issues with the Atlas Centaur upper stage valves. Despite resolving various pre-launch glitches, the mission now awaits another attempt to make its historic crewed flight.", "source": {"uri": "wonderfulengineering.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "2024-06-379891735", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "16:19:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T16:19:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T16:19:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://foreignaffairs.co.nz/2024/06/06/mil-osi-usa-liftoff-nasa-astronauts-pilot-first-starliner-crewed-test-to-station/", "title": "MIL-OSI USA: LIFTOFF! NASA Astronauts Pilot First Starliner Crewed Test to Station", "body": "NASA astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams are safely in orbit on the first crewed flight test aboard Boeing's Starliner spacecraft bound for the International Space Station.\n\nAs part of NASA's Boeing Crew Flight Test, the astronauts lifted off at 10:52 a.m. EDT Wednesday on a ULA (United Launch Alliance) Atlas V rocket from Space Launch Complex-41 at Cape Canaveral Space Force Station in Florida on an end-to-end test of the Starliner system.\n\n\"Two bold NASA astronauts are well on their way on this historic first test flight of a brand-new spacecraft,\" said NASA Administrator Bill Nelson. \"Boeing's Starliner marks a new chapter of American exploration. Human spaceflight is a daring task - but that's why it's worth doing. It's an exciting time for NASA, our commercial partners, and the future of exploration. Go Starliner, Go Butch and Suni!\"\n\nAs part of NASA's Commercial Crew Program, the flight test will help validate the transportation system, launch pad, rocket, spacecraft, in-orbit operations capabilities, and return to Earth with astronauts aboard as the agency prepares to certify Starliner for rotational missions to the space station. Starliner previously flew two uncrewed orbital flights, including a test to and from the space station, along with a pad abort demonstration.\n\n\"With Starliner's launch, separation from the rocket, and arrival on orbit, Boeing's Crew Flight Test is right on track,\" said Mark Nappi, vice president and program manager of Boeing's Commercial Crew Program. \"Everyone is focused on giving Suni and Butch a safe, comfortable, ride and performing a successful test mission from start to finish.\"\n\nDuring Starliner's flight, Boeing will monitor a series of automatic spacecraft maneuvers from its mission control center in Houston. NASA teams will monitor space station operations throughout the flight from the Mission Control Center at the agency's Johnson Space Center in Houston.\n\n\"Flying crew on Starliner represents over a decade of work by the Commercial Crew Program and our partners at Boeing and ULA,\" said Steve Stich, manager, Commercial Crew Program, at NASA's Johnson Space Center in Houston. \"For many of us, this is a career-defining moment bringing on a new crew transportation capability for our agency and our nation. We are going to take it one step at a time, putting Starliner through its paces, and remaining vigilant until Butch and Suni safely touch down back on Earth at the conclusion of this test flight.\"\n\nStarliner will autonomously dock to the forward-facing port of the station's Harmony module at approximately 12:15 p.m. Thursday, June 6, and remain at the orbital laboratory for about a week.\n\nWilmore and Williams will help verify the spacecraft is performing as intended by testing the environmental control system, the displays and control system, and by maneuvering the thrusters, among other tests during flight.\n\nAfter a safe arrival at the space station, Wilmore and Williams will join the Expedition 71 crew of NASA astronauts Michael Barratt, Matt Dominick, Tracy C. Dyson, and Jeanette Epps, and Roscosmos cosmonauts Nikolai Chub, Alexander Grebenkin, and Oleg Kononenko.\n\nNASA's arrival and in-flight event coverage is as follows (all times Eastern and subject to change based on real-time operations):\n\nMission coverage will continue on NASA Television channels throughout Starliner's flight and resume on NASA+ prior to docking.\n\nThursday, June 69:30 a.m. - Arrival coverage begins on NASA+, the NASA app, and YouTube, and continues on NASA Television and the agency's website.\n\n12:15 p.m. - Targeted docking\n\n2 p.m. - Hatch opening\n\n2:20 p.m. - Welcome remarks\n\n3:30 p.m. - Post-docking news conference at NASA Johnson with the following participants:\n\nNASA Associate Administrator Jim Free\n\nSteve Stich, manager, NASA's Commercial Crew Program\n\nJeff Arend, manager for systems engineering and integration, NASA's International Space Station Office\n\nMark Nappi, vice president and program manager, Commercial Crew Program, Boeing\n\nCoverage of the post-docking news conference will air live on NASA+, NASA Television, the NASA app, YouTube, and the agency's website.\n\n5:50 p.m. - NASA Administrator Bill Nelson, Deputy Administrator Pam Melroy, Associate Administrator Jim Free, Associate Administrator for Space Operations Ken Bowersox, and Johnson Space Center Director Vanessa Wyche will speak with Wilmore and Williams about their launch aboard the Starliner spacecraft.\n\nCoverage of the Earth to space call will air live on NASA+, NASA Television, the NASA app, YouTube, and the agency's website.\n\nSaturday, June 8\n\n8:50 a.m. - NASA astronauts Wilmore and Williams will provide a tour of Starliner.\n\nCoverage of the in-orbit event will stream live on NASA+, NASA Television, the NASA app, YouTube, and the agency's website.\n\nMonday, June 10\n\n11 a.m. - Williams will speak to students from Sunita L. Williams Elementary School in Needham, Massachusetts, in an event aboard the space station.\n\nCoverage of the Earth to space call will air live on NASA+, NASA Television, the NASA app, YouTube, and the agency's website.\n\nTuesday, June 11\n\n3:15 p.m. - Wilmore will speak to students from Tennessee Tech University in an event aboard the space station.\n\nCoverage of the Earth to space call will air live on NASA+, NASA Television, the NASA app, YouTube, and the agency's website.\n\nMeet NASA's Crew\n\nWilmore is the commander for the mission. A veteran of two spaceflights, Wilmore has 178 days in space under his belt. In 2009, he served as a pilot aboard space shuttle Atlantis for the STS-129 mission. Additionally, Wilmore served as a flight engineer for Expedition 41 until November 2014, when he assumed command of the space station after arrival of the Expedition 42 crew. He returned to Earth the following March. Prior to his selection by NASA in 2000, the father of two obtained both his bachelor's degree and master's degree in Electrical Engineering from Tennessee Technological University, Cookeville, before graduating with another master's degree in Aviation Systems from the University of Tennessee, Knoxville. He is also a graduate of the United States Naval Test Pilot School, Patuxent River, Maryland, and has completed four operational deployments during his tenure as a fleet naval officer and aviator.\n\nWilliams is the spacecraft pilot for the flight test. Williams has spent 322 days in space across two missions: Expedition 14/15 in 2006 through 2007, and Expedition 32/33 in 2012. The Massachusetts native also conducted seven spacewalks, totaling 50 hours and 40 minutes. Before her career began with NASA in 1998, Williams graduated with her bachelor's degree in Physical Science from the U.S. Naval Academy, Annapolis, Maryland, before obtaining her master's degree in Engineering Management from the Florida Institute of Technology, Melbourne. In total, she has logged more than 3,000 flight hours in over 30 different aircraft.\n\nNASA's Commercial Crew Program has delivered on its goal of safe, reliable, and cost-effective transportation to and from the International Space Station from the United States through a partnership with American private industry. This partnership is changing the arc of human spaceflight history by opening access to low Earth orbit and the space station to more people, science, and commercial opportunities. The space station remains the springboard to NASA's next great leap in space exploration, including future missions to the Moon under Artemis and, eventually, Mars.\n\nLearn more about NASA's Commercial Crew program at:\n\nhttps://www.nasa.gov/commercialcrew\n\n-end-\n\nJosh Finch / Jimi Russell / Claire O'SheaHeadquarters, Washington202-358-1100joshua.a.finch@nasa.gov / james.j.russell@nasa.gov / claire.a.o'shea@nasa.gov\n\nSteven Siceloff / Danielle Sempsrott / Stephanie PlucinskyKennedy Space Center, Florida321-867-2468steven.p.siceloff@nasa.gov / Each companies' funding has grown to $4.8 billion and $3.1 billion, respectively, according to NASA.\n\nWhile SpaceX has reliably been transporting astronauts and supplies to the ISS, Boeing's project is years behind schedule and has racked up $1.5 billion in unplanned development costs, Reuters reported.\n\nThe Boeing Starliner remains grounded: See the challenges that have delayed its launch\n\nHere's a timeline of Boeing and its Starliner program.\n\nTimeline: Boeing Starliner launch delays and other events\n\nBoeing looks for success after bumpy 2024\n\nA successful Starliner mission could help Boeing rebound in the public eye from ongoing issues with its 737 Max jets, including the grounding of the planes after an Alaska Airlines 737 Max lost a door plug during a flight in January.\n\n\"It's been hugely embarrassing for Boeing,\" Jonathan McDowell, an astronomer at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics, told Wired in May. \"It fits in with the general narrative of Boeing having lost its way.\"\n\nBoeing is a longtime NASA contractor, having collaborated on the Saturn V rocket in the Apollo program and the Space Shuttle program, according to Space.com.\n\nContributing: Reuters; Brooke Edwards, Jamie Groh and Rick Neale of Florida Today.\n\nFollow Mike Snider on X and Threads: @mikesnider & mikegsnider.\n\nWhat's everyone talking about? {"uri": "8163197035", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "15:47:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T15:47:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T15:46:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://wcfcourier.com/news/nation-world/science/boeing-launches-nasa-astronauts-for-the-first-time-after-years-of-delays/article_acce66e0-66ee-5b10-9394-186f7f8fc754.html", "title": "Boeing launches NASA astronauts for the first time after years of delays", "body": "CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla. -- Boeing launched astronauts for the first time Wednesday, belatedly joining SpaceX as a second taxi service for NASA.\n\nA pair of NASA test pilots blasted off aboard Boeing's Starliner capsule for the International Space Station, the first to fly the new spacecraft.\n\nThe trip by Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams was expected to take 25 hours, with an arrival Thursday. They will spend just over a week at the orbiting lab before climbing back into Starliner for a remote desert touchdown in the western U.S. on June 14.\n\nYears late because of spacecraft flaws, Starliner's crew debut comes as the company struggles with unrelated safety issues on its airplane side.\n\nPeople are also reading... Names released in fatal motorcycle crash Deere to lay off global production, salaried employees at end of third quarter One killed, one injured in I-380 motorcycle accident Saturday night at Waterloo Waterloo man arrested in teen-enticing sting Reinbeck man detained after search turns up gun, cash, drugs UPDATE: Deere posts notice of 123 layoffs, 49 in Waterloo; global production, salaried employees cut Waterloo bicyclist suffers serious injuries after colliding with truck Waterloo council could turn old church into housing, day care Masic, Neff vie for Black Hawk County sheriff's position in Tuesday's primary election Man arrested for allegedly stealing Waterloo school district truck Iowa restaurant inspection update: Green slime, moldy meat, unlicensed eateries Fire destroys garage and vehicles in Waterloo Iowa Supreme Court overturns conviction in 2020 fatal shooting Part I: The Right Coach 12th Street housing development to be considered by Cedar Falls council\n\nWilmore and Williams -- retired Navy captains and former space station residents -- stressed repeatedly before the launch that they had full confidence in Boeing's ability to get it right with this test flight. Crippled by bad software, Starliner's initial test flight in 2019 without a crew had to be repeated before NASA would let its astronauts strap in. The 2022 do-over went much better, but parachute problems later cropped up and flammable tape had to be removed from the capsule.\n\nWednesday's launch was the third attempt with astronauts since early May, coming after a pair of rocket-related problems, most recently last weekend. A small helium leak in the spacecraft's propulsion system also caused delays, but managers decided the leak was manageable and not a safety issue.\n\n\"I know it's been a long road to get here,\" NASA's commercial crew program manager Steve Stich said before the weekend delay.\n\nBoeing was hired alongside Elon Musk's SpaceX a decade ago to ferry NASA's astronauts to and from the space station. The space agency wanted two competing U.S. companies for the job in the wake of the space shuttles' retirement, paying $4.2 billion to Boeing and just over half that to SpaceX, which refashioned the capsule it was using to deliver station supplies.\n\nSpaceX launched astronauts into orbit in 2020, becoming the first private business to achieve what only three countries -- Russia, the U.S. and China -- had mastered. It has taken nine crews to the space station for NASA and three private groups for a Houston company that charters flights.\n\nThe liftoff from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station was the 100th of an Atlas V for rocket maker United Launch Alliance. It was the first ride for astronauts on an Atlas rocket since John Glenn's Mercury era more than 60 years ago; the rocket usually launches satellites and other spacecraft.\n\nDespite the Atlas V's perfect record, the human presence cranked up the tension for the scores of NASA and Boeing employees gathered at Cape Canaveral and Mission Control in Houston.\n\nBoeing's Starliner and SpaceX's Dragon are designed to be fully autonomous and reusable. Wilmore and Williams occasionally will take manual control of Starliner on their way to the space station, to check out its systems.\n\nIf the mission goes well, NASA will alternate between SpaceX and Boeing for taxi flights, beginning next year. The backup pilot for this test flight, Mike Fincke, will strap in for Starliner's next trip.\n\n\"When you have a new spacecraft, you need to learn all about it and this has been a great exercise,\" Fincke told reporters late last week.\n\nThe Associated Press Health and Science Department receives support from the Howard Hughes Medical Institute's Science and Educational Media Group. The AP is solely responsible for all content.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "2024-06-379921999", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "16:50:35", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T16:50:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T15:04:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/liftoff-finally-boeing-starliner-launches-first-crew-on-third-try/article_394eaebd-786d-55b2-8625-a60d5bf67a23.html", "title": "Liftoff, finally: Boeing Starliner launches first crew on third try", "body": "The Boeing Starliner capsule blasted off atop a United Launch Alliance Atlas V rocket at 10:52 am (1452 GMT) from the Cape Canaveral Space Force Station in Florida\n\nBoeing on Wednesday launched its very first astronauts bound for the International Space Station aboard a Starliner capsule, which joins a select club of spacecraft to carry humans beyond Earth.\n\nThe third time turned out to be the charm for the aerospace giant, after two previous bids to fly with crew were aborted late into the countdown, for technical reasons.\n\nAstronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams, both of whom have two previous spaceflights under their belts, blasted off at 10:52 am (1452 GMT) from the Cape Canaveral Space Force Station in Florida, for a roughly one-week stay at the station.\n\n\"Suni and I are honored to share this dream of spaceflight with each and every one of you,\" Wilmore, who is commander of the test flight, said just before liftoff. \"Let's put some fire in this rocket, and let's push it to the heavens.\"\n\nStarliner becomes just the sixth type of US-built spaceship to fly NASA astronauts, following the Mercury, Gemini and Apollo programs in the 1960s and 1970s, the Space Shuttle from 1981 to 2011, and SpaceX's Crew Dragon from 2020.\n\nThe Starliner program has been beset by years of safety scares and delays, and a successful mission will offer Boeing a much-needed reprieve from the intense safety concerns surrounding its passenger jets.\n\nNASA meanwhile is looking to certify Boeing as a second commercial operator to ferry crews to the ISS -- something Elon Musk's SpaceX has already been doing for the US space agency for four years.\n\n- Embarrassing setbacks -\n\nBoth companies received multibillion-dollar contracts in 2014 to develop their crew capsules, following the end of the Space Shuttle program that left the US temporarily reliant on Russian rockets for rides.\n\nBoeing, with its 100-year history, was heavily favored, but its program fell badly behind.\n\nSetbacks ranged from a software bug that put the spaceship on a bad trajectory on its first uncrewed test, to the discovery that the cabin was filled with flammable electrical tape after the second.\n\nThe first crewed launch attempt on May 6 was scuppered in the final hours due to a buzzy valve on the United Launch Alliance Atlas V rocket the capsule sits atop.\n\nThen on Saturday, things were even more dramatic with liftoff aborted with less than four minutes left on the countdown clock as the ground launch computer went into an automatic hold.\n\nThe problem was later traced to a faulty power supply source connected to the computer, with the malfunctioning unit since replaced.\n\nIn both cases, Wilmore and Williams were strapped in and ready to go, only to be forced to return to strict quarantine in their quarters.\n\nThe pair of ex-Navy test pilots might have been forgiven for thinking they were stuck in Groundhog Day as they waved their goodbyes to their families on Wednesday morning and headed to the astrovan that led them to the launchpad.\n\nWhile teams worked to replace the faulty rocket valve that postponed the first crewed launch attempt, a small helium leak located in one of Starliner's thrusters came to light.\n\nRather than replace the seal, which would require taking the spaceship apart in its factory, NASA and Boeing officials declared it safe enough to fly as is.\n\nThe astronauts will now be charged with putting Starliner through the wringer, including taking manual control of the spacecraft on its way to the ISS.\n\nDuring their stay on the research platform, they will continue to evaluate the craft, including simulating whether the ship can be used as a safe haven in the event of problems on the orbital outpost.\n\nAfter undocking, Starliner will re-enter the atmosphere, with the crew experiencing 3.5G as they slow down from 17,500 miles an hour (28,000 kph) to a gentle parachute and airbag-assisted landing in the western United States.\n\nia/des\n\nMore from this {"uri": "8163251030", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-05", "time": "16:25:16", "dateTime": "2024-06-05T16:25:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-05T16:23:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://brudirect.com/news.php?id=188107", "title": " Read More", "body": "The spacecraft successfully blasted off after a series of delays.\n\nBoeing's first Starliner flight with a human crew onboard has successfully blasted off to space on top of United Launch Alliance's Atlas V rocket, almost a month after it was originally scheduled to launch. NASA astronauts Butch Wilmore and Sunita Williams entered the Starliner capsule and completed necessary checks by 10:08AM ET. Less than 30 minutes after the astronauts entered the capsule, the CEO ULA tweeted that the company was \"working an issue with topping valves on the ground side\" and that it was running the fix through its Software Integration Lab (SIL) before it's executed. In the end, ULA was able to implement a workaround, and the spacecraft lifted off at 10:52am ET.\n\nBack on May 6, the companies scrubbed the flight two hours after it was originally scheduled to launch after their ground teams detected \"anomalous behavior by the pressure regulation valve in the liquid oxygen tank of the Centaur upper stage of the ULA Atlas V launch vehicle.\" The valve was replaced and the Starliner teams were ready to make another launch attempt when they encountered another issue: They found a \"small helium leak\" in the spacecraft's service module.\n\nThe astronauts are beginning ingress into #Starliner -- taking their seats in the spacecraft. Teams will assist in a series of checks, including umbilical hook ups, communications checks and suit checks. The astronauts will also check the spacecraft so they are ready for flight. pic.twitter.com/aGfZoq9oPd\n\nNASA and Boeing had to push back Starliner's launch date in order to investigate the leak and figure out how it would affect the flight. They eventually determined that it didn't pose a threat to the mission's safety, so they scheduled a launch attempt for June 1. Last week's launch was also scrubbed last minute due to the \"computer ground launch sequencer not loading into the correct operational configuration after proceeding into terminal count.\"\n\nAside from the NASA astronauts, Starliner flew with 760 pounds of cargo, including 300 pounds of food and other supplies requested by the crew that's currently onboard the International Space Station. Wilmore and Williams will spend eight days on the ISS conducting tests to help determine whether the Starliner is ready for regular flights to the orbiting laboratory. NASA said that if the mission is completed successfully, it will begin the final process of \"certifying Starliner and its systems for crewed rotation missions to the space station.\"\n\nIf you have "eng-9622079", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-05-06", "textStart": 765, "textEnd": 770}, {"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-06-01", "textStart":
